"}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not merge

I've got a few concerns.

First, the reservation code should be copied to Oslo first. I have some qualms with it and think it needs improvement (for example, the driver to expire times currently does nothing). Rather than having to maintain our own fork of it and improve it ourselves, I think it should live in Oslo so if we do change it, everyone else can enjoy those changes, plus we will get any benefits from improvements other teams wish to make.

Second, it seems the reservation logic is being applied at the wsgi layer in the request phase. It should work instead on the model layer (maybe a better name is the logic layer - anything that isn't controller or view). This is a good idea anyway and also how Nova implements it (check out the compute api class at https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py).

Third, I feel like an attempt was made to keep the quota changes from affecting the existing code- the wsgi helper code you've submitted goes to some effort to wrap every single request and only apply quotas if it matches a pattern. I don't think that's necessary. Instead, consider creating a function which just makes a reservation, calls a provisioning function, and then if the function raises an exception rolls back, otherwise commits the reservation. It might look like this (I'm spitballing here so this code may have mistakes):

def run_with_quota(context, resource_deltas, provision_function):
    quota_engine.reserve(context.tenant, {resource_name:delta})
    try:
        provision_function()
    except:
        quota_engine.rollback()
        raise
    else:
        quota_engine.commit()

You could then put this in for example reddwarf/instance/models.py in the create method of  like so:
    @classmethod
    def create(cls, context, name, flavor_id, image_id,
               databases, users, service_type, volume_size):
        client = create_nova_client(context)
        try:
            flavor = client.flavors.get(flavor_id)
        except nova_exceptions.NotFound:
            raise exception.FlavorNotFound(uuid=flavor_id)

        db_info = DBInstance.create(name=name, flavor_id=flavor_id,
                                    tenant_id=context.tenant,
                                    volume_size=volume_size,
                                    task_status=InstanceTasks.BUILDING)
        LOG.debug(_("Tenant %s created new Reddwarf instance %s...")
                  % (context.tenant, db_info.id))

        service_status = InstanceServiceStatus.create(
            instance_id=db_info.id,
            status=ServiceStatuses.NEW)

        if CONF.reddwarf_dns_support:
            dns_client = create_dns_client(context)
            hostname = dns_client.determine_hostname(db_info.id)
            db_info.hostname = hostname
            db_info.save()
        # new code:
        def provision():
          task_api.API(context).create_instance(db_info.id, name, flavor_id,
                                              flavor.ram, image_id, databases,
                                              users, service_type,
                                              volume_size)
        run_with_quota(context, {"instances": 1, "volumes": volume_size},
                       provision)
        # end new code
        return SimpleInstance(context, db_info, service_status)


Finally, though reservations is written as a general purpose abstraction that can apply to *any* resource, we've hard coded the names of specific resources everywhere. Nova does this too, but it should try to avoid doing it as well.

For example, the view of the mgmt call looks like this:
return {
 'quotas': {
                  'instances': self.quotas['instances'].hard_limit,
                  'volumes': self.quotas['volumes'].hard_limit
              }

Instead, the code could be like this:
rtn = {}
for resource_name, quota in self.quotas.items():
    rtn[key] = quota.hard_limit
return rtn'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

As for OSLO, Vipul and Mike caught me up on the conversation I appreciate now why this is being copied in. My only concern now is that since this will not be in Oslo we need to make sure we test it as well as possible. It looks like you have covered this well with unit tests, but I'll need to take a second look at the test coverage.

Second point, I appreciate the thoughtfulness inherent inmaking this live in the wsgi for Rax's sake. However we actually are going to be using this quota logic as well. Repose actually works by calling the service it wraps for absolute limits and then forwarding the response. So we'll be consuming this feature. :) And I think it would make much more sense to put it in the model (aka logic) layer rather than in the wsgi (aka REST service) layer.

If we want other users to be able to turn this off cleanly, I suggest we use flags. That approach (which lives in the modules) would result in far fewer lines of code and config settings and ultimately give us fewer bugs."}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

have not looked at the code yet but its not referencing a BP"}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Tim, 

Thanks for the thorough review. These are quite a bit of change. Let me try if i can sweet talk to you out of this so that we can meet somewhere in the middle :-)

For your first suggestion, I think it is a great idea to move the reservation code to oslo but im not sure how much time and effort this will take. We will have to design the reservation code in a way that is transparent and applicable to all openstack projects and frankly, i dont think reddwarf's reservation code is designed for that. Nova and Cinder have their own reservation code in their projects and I think their reservation code is more mature and proven which would make it a better candidate to be moved to oslo instead.

For your second point, the reservation logic was designed and intended to live in the wsgi layer. The reasons we decided to do this is primarily that it does not infiltrate nor pollute the current code in the api/service. This keeps the actual provisioning logic much cleaner and less prone to new bugs. We wanted to maintain a separation of responsibility in the design. Another way we were looking to do this was by annotations. Another reason is that we wanted to design quota in a way that was easily bypassed or disabled. We knew Rax was using a different quota engine (repose), so we wanted to make it easily disabled. The quota engine can be easily disabled by removing the filter name in the paste-api.ini file.

Your third suggestion is great. However it would be hard to implement it without taking the reservation code out of the wsgi layer and into the api/service. But you gave me an idea and ill use your logic to come up with something similar.

Your last point is great as well and ill implement it as such.

Thanks again for the review Tim. I understand your concerns. Part of this is my fault because i didnt have a BP with the design, which i will do now. I will create this BP with the current design of the quota and Ill let the core devs comment and review the design and apply changes. Once the BP is approved, ill make the necessary changes to the code."}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Hi Tim,

I responded your question in the patch comments. That volume quota check is to make sure that an instance does not have a volume that exceeds a maximum. The new quota feature just makes sure that the total of volume allocated has not exceed the total maximum across all instances for that tenant. We can incorporate this check into the quota but i would rather get this initial work merged first and then we can create a BP to handle the volume-quota-per-instance refactoring. Talk to Robert Myers for more information.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-05 19:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Quota feature

Quota check for create/delete/resize volume
Quota is implemented as a decorator, which can be easy enabled and disabled if wanted.
The quota feature uses a reservation system that reserves resources prior to usage.

BP https://blueprints.launchpad.net/reddwarf/+spec/quotas

Change-Id: I5df82c8f1d7b40311b5d5d7301992607f98e9b2a

[{'created': '2013-02-26 11:22:53.000000000', 'message': "Unpin pam dependency version

Fixes bug #1133240

keystone has always pinned the pam dependency to 0.1.4

  pam>=0.1.4

this version was released in November 2009 and there hasn't been a
release since. I can't even find a version control repo for the
project.

There's no particular reason to expect a future version would break us
and, indeed, we want to find out about it if it happens.

Change-Id: I2becf47c9d2566e2c3496ae15ca886b737006a92
"}]
commit_message:
Unpin pam dependency version

Fixes bug #1133240

keystone has always pinned the pam dependency to 0.1.4

  pam>=0.1.4

this version was released in November 2009 and there hasn't been a
release since. I can't even find a version control repo for the
project.

There's no particular reason to expect a future version would break us
and, indeed, we want to find out about it if it happens.

Change-Id: I2becf47c9d2566e2c3496ae15ca886b737006a92

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 20:10:14.000000000', 'message': "Imporove db.sqlalchemy.api._validate_unique_server_name method

This method is called by instance_create and instance_update.
If parameter CONF.osapi_compute_unqiue_server_name_scope is set to
'global' or 'project' then it has terrible performance.

Algorithm was next:
1) Get all instances and all connected data (5 joinloads..) in global
   (or project).
2) Compare hostname with hostnames in instances (locally)

Now:
1) Get only count of instances with same hostname in global (or project).
2) If count > 0 raise Exception.

Change-Id: I35ea121c3f906b4fff11c38bafa2ab33200bd6b2
"}]
commit_message:
Imporove db.sqlalchemy.api._validate_unique_server_name method

This method is called by instance_create and instance_update.
If parameter CONF.osapi_compute_unqiue_server_name_scope is set to
'global' or 'project' then it has terrible performance.

Algorithm was next:
1) Get all instances and all connected data (5 joinloads..) in global
   (or project).
2) Compare hostname with hostnames in instances (locally)

Now:
1) Get only count of instances with same hostname in global (or project).
2) If count > 0 raise Exception.

Change-Id: I35ea121c3f906b4fff11c38bafa2ab33200bd6b2

commit_message:
L3 port delete prevention: do not raise if no IP on port

Bug #1104337

This patch alters the prevent_l3_port_deletion logic.
PortInUse is raised only if the port has a device owner in
(router_interface, router_gateway, floatingip) and an IP
address.
If no IP address is found on the port the port itself can
be considered stale and therefore deleted as any association
with l3 entities would be void.

Change-Id: I9d711b2a9d2cbcc8be481f1751f51fe5b9f01327

commit_message:
Fixes linuxbridge agent downs with tap device deletion timing issue

Fixes bug 1136264

Add try/except in deamon loop for preventing agent broken down by
unhandled exception.

Change-Id: I99a4f2b485f134b240630a895378d0f61d6382d8

That wait parameter is only for logging purposes. I added it as a quick hack to filter out log messages for 404 errors from wait for delete functions. (See: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17227/ ) Without it there are error messages in a successful tempest run's log. (Look at the jenkins log for this commit you'll see them)

I'm fine with removing the parameter, but only if there is an alternative solution for the error messages in a successful tempest run's log."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-05 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
RestClient remove wait parameter from the get method

is_resource_deleted in the past worked like a wait method in several
cases.
Now we can safely remove the additional wait arguments form the
RestClient method signatures.

Change-Id: Ieebdef3d10876e6906ead8554680e2486ec8ce07

[{'created': '2013-03-05 16:02:11.000000000', 'message': "Stop heat services from logging to stderr by default

Change the configuration files to set use_stderr to False by
default.  Oslo's log sets use_stderr to True by default, and
the only reasonable way to override is via the config files.

Fixes: Bug #1146848
"}]
commit_message:
Stop heat services from logging to stderr by default

Change the configuration files to set use_stderr to False by
default.  Oslo's log sets use_stderr to True by default, and
the only reasonable way to override is via the config files.

Change-Id: Ibc4ac3b8cb5d7478260d5d014eb48860bae4bc0b
Fixes: Bug #1146848

[{'created': '2013-03-04 22:05:32.000000000', 'message': 'Correct getchildren() usage in list_addresses()

This commit fixes the usage of getchildren in the list_addresses
method. Previously, the method was called on body which was a string.
This commit corrects the behavior and runs the method on an etree
object.

Fixes bug 1132796

Change-Id: Iafb8d51257b7bcbfbcf9141c3d424c601a186a89
'}]
commit_message:
Correct getchildren() usage in list_addresses()

This commit fixes the usage of getchildren in the list_addresses
method. Previously, the method was called on body which was a string.
This commit corrects the behavior and runs the method on an etree
object.

Fixes bug 1132796

Change-Id: Iafb8d51257b7bcbfbcf9141c3d424c601a186a89

commit_message:
Enable VM DHCP request to reach DHCP agent

When using the firewall driver IptablesFirewallDriver and the
default INPUT and FORWARD rules are DISCARD then the DHCP
request from the VM is discarded prior to getting to the dnsmasq.

A new rule will be added that enables DHCP requests to pass.

This fixes bug 1131223

Change-Id: I50fad5b63c3c4b22a5d828e3e89353c1ed723332

commit_message:
Ignore flymake output files

Emacs' flymake mode creates a copy of the regular
python file and then runs pyflakes and pep8 against
the copy. Sometimes these copies are hanging around
when nose looks for test files, so tell nose to ignore
the copies to avoid duplicate tests.

Change-Id: I117cd083cf7a7c37d614bbae80a33ce73d2cb4dd
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-05 04:06:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix 'to integer' conversion of max and min count values

Until now when you used values non-integer to max_count and/or min_count the
coercion worked like: min_count = int(2.5) so min_count received 2 instead of
raise bad request.

Convert to string before coerce to int solves the problem since int coercion
cannot convert from a string which is not a perfect int.

Change-Id: Ifaa9910e13614554d1769e71e8eba9587ec5a13b
"}, {'created': '2013-03-05 13:01:24.000000000', 'message': "Fix 'to integer' conversion of max and min count values

Until now when you used values non-integer to max_count and/or min_count the
coercion worked like: min_count = int(2.5) so min_count received 2 instead of
raise bad request.

Convert to string before coerce to int solves the problem since int coercion
cannot convert from a string which is not a perfect int.

Change-Id: Ifaa9910e13614554d1769e71e8eba9587ec5a13b
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'to integer' conversion of max and min count values

Until now when you used values non-integer to max_count and/or min_count the
coercion worked like: min_count = int(2.5) so min_count received 2 instead of
raise bad request.

Convert to string before coerce to int solves the problem since int coercion
cannot convert from a string which is not a perfect int.

commit_message:
Backport of fix for 24-hour failure of pki.

A 401 from the admin token was being treated as an invalid user token
and the admin token was never re-requested. This would cause all
services to incorrectly report all tokens as invalid after the service
had been running for 24 hours. This change re-requests the admin token
and attempts to revalidate instead of returning 401.

Original commit message follows:

fixes bug 1074172

updated diablo token based on output from diablo/stable keystone
added expiry to example tokens for test_auth_middleware
added a stack based HTTP response to test_auth_middleware to verify
sequencing

Change-Id: I738b0e9c1a0e62ad86adb95ec0b73f621513f7d4
(cherry picked from commit 7cc02c80cfb1976271fa8b6271091fcd35c1cb34)

[{'created': '2013-03-01 16:50:57.000000000', 'message': 'chown -R to ensure that stack user owns data_dir

The fix for bug #1129748 tightens some permissions on image
directories.  This breaks the devstack gate jobs, which were
relying on wide-open permissions.  chowning recursively should
ensure that all the directories are owned by the stack user,
so the gate tests work with tighter permissions.

Change-Id: I09be54bff6d8f9c3f7f599d6e5ada6431beb7c31
'}]
commit_message:
chown -R to ensure that stack user owns data_dir

The fix for bug #1129748 tightens some permissions on image
directories.  This breaks the devstack gate jobs, which were
relying on wide-open permissions.  chowning recursively should
ensure that all the directories are owned by the stack user,
so the gate tests work with tighter permissions.

Change-Id: I09be54bff6d8f9c3f7f599d6e5ada6431beb7c31

commit_message:
Ensure that FORWARD rule also supports DHCP

The previous fix only addressed the INPUT rules and not the
FORWARD rule.

Adds FORWARD rule to ensure that DHCP traffic is forwarded correctly.

Fixes bug 1131223

Change-Id: Ie0d365ba1ba1014bdd2bfc944123c17c4e415d6e

commit_message:
Quantum PLUMgrid Plugin Support

The commit introduces devstack support for the Quantum PLUMgrid Plugin.

Change-Id: Idc4d97a65f9e7669075609aafe7ffc8286f0b94a
Implements: blueprint plumgrid-plugin

Baremetal deploy helper should set oflag=direct when dd'ing images onto
iSCSI targets, so that it doesn't waste the local page cache.

Fixes bug 1114633.

Change-Id: Ia674afb34aff7b842cfcd520ecb7b75dc21944fa

commit_message:
Baremetal deploy helper sets ODIRECT.

Baremetal deploy helper should set oflag=direct when dd'ing images onto
iSCSI targets, so that it doesn't waste the local page cache.

Fixes bug 1114633.

Change-Id: Ia674afb34aff7b842cfcd520ecb7b75dc21944fa

commit_message:
Standarize ip validation along the code

Details:
 - Use the nova/utils.py validations along the code
 - refactor ipv4 validator to looks like ipv6 validator
 - interprets ip validations exceptions as Invalid IP values

Change-Id: Ia506c00510a066e167d3dcd9dd371a371129a9dd

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 16:16:22.000000000', 'message': "swift backup service checks version during restore

Modified swift backup service to check metadata version during restore
and raise an error if the backup version isn't a version that the
service knows how to handle. The versions which can be handled are
described in a dictionary mapping versions to methods which can handle
them. This will facilitate graceful handling of newer backup formats by
the swift backup service when we introduce changes.

Fixes bug: 1136174

Change-Id: Id7d05848fd448ce21f641e5cd6945477702cbe38
"}]
commit_message:
swift backup service checks version during restore

Modified swift backup service to check metadata version during restore
and raise an error if the backup version isn't a version that the
service knows how to handle. The versions which can be handled are
described in a dictionary mapping versions to methods which can handle
them. This will facilitate graceful handling of newer backup formats by
the swift backup service when we introduce changes.

Fixes bug: 1136174

Change-Id: Id7d05848fd448ce21f641e5cd6945477702cbe38

What's the use case for this? Which OpenStack project needs it and why?"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-03-01 15:36:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We need to add microsecond precision timestamps on tokens in keystone, and would like to have them in an ISO 8601 extended date time format ('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%fZ'). We could use strtime() and parse_strtime() with our own format string, but there's no reason why microseconds shouldn't be an option out of the box with the isotime functions.

I'd be fine with:

  isotime(microseconds=True)

(where microseconds defaults to False) and perhaps let parse_isotime() try/except on the two formats (with and without microseconds) before failing."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-03-01 15:42:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

subject: Fail validation when an unknown property is supplied in a template.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-28 05:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/2182 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/1/check/gate-heat-python26/2162 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/1/check/gate-heat-python27/2161 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/1/check/dev-heat-coverage/884 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-02-28 12:29:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure about this - creating an event for something which is really a template validation error seems wrong.

A bit of googling seems to indicate that AWS treat this situation as an error and set the stack to CREATE_FAILED, with the reason specifying the unsupported property.  I think doing it this way would be better and more intuitive than silently creating events which users may or may not look at."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-02-28 22:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I did it this way because of a comment by zane in the bug:
 "
 A possible downside of enforcing this would be that it 
 could limit upwards compatibility. We definitely need at 
 least a warning though.
 "
 I think this highlights a short coming in the current 
 mechanism for feeding information back to the user.
 This felt like a good compromise between doing nothing
 and failing the stack create.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-02-28 23:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, FWIW, I disagree with zaneb's comment - we need to enforce the schema and return a validation failure in this situation IMO.  

I don't see how it limits upwards compatibility at all, since presumably new heat versions will support a superset of previous properties.  

It could limit *backwards* compatibility, but we only currently support one AWS template version anyway AFAIK.  

Adding Zane to the reviewer list for his opinion... :)"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-03-01 08:09:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To clarify my meaning in that comment, Steve is thinking of backwards compatibility; upwards compatibility is the opposite of that.

Say that cloud provider A rolls out a Grizzly-based OpenStack cloud, and then later cloud provider B rolls out a Havana-based cloud, where we've added a bunch of properties to resources. Templates written for cloud provider B that use these properties will now fail to launch on cloud provider A if we strictly enforce properties. This is a problem that AWS does not have. The question is, do we care?

One argument would be that the property is obviously added to mean something, so if we can't handle it we should fail and make the user edit his template.
Another argument would be that we should make it possible for automated tools to shift templates between cloud providers without editing or necessarily moving to lowest-common-denominator templates.

I can see the merits of both arguments, and I think some debate is required.

Have at it :D"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-03-04 08:53:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> One argument would be that the property is obviously added to mean something, so if we can't handle it we should fail and make the user edit his template.

This - it then makes it obvious to the user that certain features aren't supported (or that they have typos in their template, which this patch will make totally non-obvious).  

Versioning the templates is better handled either by the user using traditional tools, git etc, or via versioning at the API level IMO.

> Another argument would be that we should make it possible for automated tools to shift templates between cloud providers without editing or necessarily moving to lowest-common-denominator templates.

So to me this implies either versioning of templates via specific API versions (which we obviously already have but it doesn't translate into versioned resource schema's AFAICS), or some migration/compatibility tool/script above the API which knows about the various template versions.

I don't think implementing a permissive "accept everything" policy in the engine is compatible with either approach.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-03-05 00:17:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-03-05 00:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-03-05 00:39:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-03-05 00:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-03-05 00:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-05 01:55:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/3/check/gate-heat-pep8/2281 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/3/check/gate-heat-python26/2263 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/3/check/gate-heat-python27/2262 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/23157/3/check/dev-heat-coverage/939 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-03-05 09:43:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Looks good. We should also be checking for this stuff in validate_template (not just stack_create/stack_update) - that would make a good follow-up patch.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-03-05 11:18:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-03-05 11:21:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fix an error in compute api snapshot_volume_backed bdm code

Stumbled upon an error similar to the one found in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23354/ where a dbm dict
item is tried to be read as an attribute.

Looked at the next couple of lines and discovered more
cases of this error.

Updates to some api tests that contain faulty fakes that
hide this error adds some coverage for this error. Rebased
this patch on the above mentioned review to be able to
change the tests, since the code path is the same and they
now hit both of these errors.

Resolves bug 1142734.

Change-Id: Ie639cd483334b6222085a139159da47ce6fa3671

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 21:35:26.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize_time() always return naive object

Currently the timeutils.normalize_time() returns naive datetime
object when parameter timestamp is an naive object or a non-UTC
aware datetime object, and returns aware datetime object if
parameter timestamp is a UTC aware datetime object.

The basic problem here is that utcoffset() of None means the object is naive
but a utcoffset() of zero means that the object is aware but represents
UTC time.

This is fragile implementation and will trigger potential issue, because
aware/native datetime is not interoperatable. For example,
"timeutils.utcnow() > timeutils.normalize_time(m)" will success at most
time, while trigger TypeError if m is a UTC aware object.

We want to normalize all objects into naive objects.

Fixes bug 1048636

Change-Id: I4a09246fa8f0dd63ca54362b877aa825d9b79772
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
(cherry picked from commit b81938dc2fec8f6e15b0b3dcb8eabc276e647af4)
'}]
commit_message:
Normalize_time() always return naive object

Currently the timeutils.normalize_time() returns naive datetime
object when parameter timestamp is an naive object or a non-UTC
aware datetime object, and returns aware datetime object if
parameter timestamp is a UTC aware datetime object.

The basic problem here is that utcoffset() of None means the object is naive
but a utcoffset() of zero means that the object is aware but represents
UTC time.

This is fragile implementation and will trigger potential issue, because
aware/native datetime is not interoperatable. For example,
"timeutils.utcnow() > timeutils.normalize_time(m)" will success at most
time, while trigger TypeError if m is a UTC aware object.

We want to normalize all objects into naive objects.

Fixes bug 1048636

Change-Id: I4a09246fa8f0dd63ca54362b877aa825d9b79772
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
(cherry picked from commit b81938dc2fec8f6e15b0b3dcb8eabc276e647af4)

commit_message:
HBase storage driver, initial version.

This is a new storage driver that supports storing of Ceilometer
data in an HBase backend. This version does not have metaquery
support yet.

Implements: blueprint hbase-storage-backend
Change-Id: Id3e7ec01434b1be30cce4f91b39461fc389a000f

This patch also needs to map this new exception type to the correct API responses in heat.api.aws.exception.map_remote_error() and heat.api.openstack.v1.util.remote_error(), modify both APIs to expect an exception in case of error, and update the unit tests for both APIs to verify the case where an exception is returned instead of the weirdly-formatted dict we had before.

It would be good to also have some finer-grained exception types, and raise them from further up the call tree, but that can be left for the future. It's probably best that this patch just stick to updating the RPC API, but it does need to change the client end of that API as well."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-19 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Validation failures now raise StackValidationFailed

This changes the way validation failures are presented
to heat-cfn as per bug 1072939

Change-Id: Iddaaf0c83c5d0df7c0143c6805096a83f8e5dc51

Change-Id: I3bc272aea1fd1ce29953d2080b58d75f5373513a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-03-04 21:11:17.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure missing period is treated consistently

return a consistent value for the period.

Fix the SQLAlchemy driver so it returns 0 for the period

commit_message:
Ensure missing period is treated consistently

Add a new test to ensure that all of the storage drivers
return a consistent value for the period.

Fix the SQLAlchemy driver so it returns 0 for the period
if no period is provided in the input to the query.

Change-Id: I3bc272aea1fd1ce29953d2080b58d75f5373513a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-03-04 03:05:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-03-04 04:56:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'd like some clarification on the "important feature" tiering, don't know that we've ever talked about this and it seems your driver is the only one that supports it.  That's fine, I just would like a good public definition of what it is.

To be clear, I have no problem with it being added, I just want to have a definition.  I also want to set up some sort of guidelines here so we don't end up with an unmanageable number of specs values being added over time.

Modifying the bool's to strings is *ok*, but I'd rather convert the extra-specs flags when we do comparisons than have to deal with limiting everything in the configs to being strings.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-03-04 09:00:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey John,

My definition of tiering is: The storage device has multiple classes of media.  Data can be placed on the media automatically according to workload or other considerations, or manually (for example, by setting additional key-values in the volume type).

As for the issue with strings and booleans and such, I agree with you.  I'm not sure how to solve the issue because most of the code is in Oslo (e.g., the capabilties filter), and I don't know the proper steps to change code there and in Cinder at the same time.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-03-04 19:26:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the clarification Avishay.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:54:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-03-05 07:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You're right.  Will split into 3 patches - stay tuned! :)"}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-03-05 07:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Will split into 3 patches.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-03 14:32:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix Storwize/SVC capability reporting errors.

After more testing of how the Storwize/SVC driver deals with
capabilities and interactions with the capability scheduler, some
errors surfaced:
1. 'storage_protocol' should be defined as a list of enabled protocols,
not simply 'iSCSI'. The extra_specs key-value would then be, for
example, storage_protocol='<in> iSCSI'.
2. Compression and tiering support were not exported as capabilities,
and are important features.
3. Boolean values for capabilities don't work because extra_specs are
all converted to unicode. The scheduler will then check, for example,
if the boolean 'True' is equal to the unicode string 'True', and will
always return False. This was an issue with the 'QoS_support' flag, as
well as the new compression and multitier flags.

Fixes bug: 1142196

Change-Id: Ib0137e98fe84621ed5c7b6e25ad7f98469854763
"}]
commit_message:
Fix Storwize/SVC capability reporting errors.

After more testing of how the Storwize/SVC driver deals with
capabilities and interactions with the capability scheduler, some
errors surfaced:
1. 'storage_protocol' should be defined as a list of enabled protocols,
not simply 'iSCSI'. The extra_specs key-value would then be, for
example, storage_protocol='<in> iSCSI'.
2. Compression and tiering support were not exported as capabilities,
and are important features.
3. Boolean values for capabilities don't work because extra_specs are
all converted to unicode. The scheduler will then check, for example,
if the boolean 'True' is equal to the unicode string 'True', and will
always return False. This was an issue with the 'QoS_support' flag, as
well as the new compression and multitier flags.

Fixes bug: 1142196

Change-Id: Ib0137e98fe84621ed5c7b6e25ad7f98469854763

[{'created': '2013-03-05 07:03:30.000000000', 'message': 'L3 port delete prevention: do not raise if no IP on port

Bug #1104337

This patch alters the prevent_l3_port_deletion logic.
PortInUse is raised only if the port has a device owner in
(router_interface, router_gateway, floatingip) and an IP
address.
If no IP address is found on the port the port itself can
be considered stale and therefore deleted as any association
with l3 entities would be void.

Change-Id: I9d711b2a9d2cbcc8be481f1751f51fe5b9f01327

Change-Id: I9d711b2a9d2cbcc8be481f1751f51fe5b9f01327

commit_message:
L3 port delete prevention: do not raise if no IP on port

Bug #1104337

This patch alters the prevent_l3_port_deletion logic.
PortInUse is raised only if the port has a device owner in
(router_interface, router_gateway, floatingip) and an IP
address.
If no IP address is found on the port the port itself can
be considered stale and therefore deleted as any association
with l3 entities would be void.

Change-Id: I9d711b2a9d2cbcc8be481f1751f51fe5b9f01327

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-08 19:29:06.000000000', 'message': 'Work In Progress - Allow User and Admin lock of an instance

The existing instance lock capability is currently restricted
to being an admin only action in the default policy.

This blueprint introduces additional functionality that allows
the lock to be used by users (to prevent accidental changes to
an instance for example), but also allows the lock to taken
by an administrator with appropriate privileges such that it
overrides any lock held by the user (for example to block
actions on a rouge instance)

The change is implemented by adding a record of the tenant
that takes the lock, which also provides an audit capability.

Aside from recording the id of the tenant the schematics of
locking an instance remain the same and are protected by
the existing policy

When unlocking an instance an additional check is made to see
if the lock is held by the owner of the instance. If it isn't
then an additional check is made against the unlock_override policy

This allows the lock and unlock policy to be changes as follows:

"compute_extension:admin_actions:lock": "rule:admin_or_owner",
"compute_extension:admin_actions:unlock": "rule:admin_or_owner",
"compute_extension:admin_actions:unlock_override": "rule:admin_api",

Change-Id: I455cbbbd3101377d431efd70d7848d96573b66ae
'}]
commit_message:
Work In Progress - Allow User and Admin lock of an instance

The existing instance lock capability is currently restricted
to being an admin only action in the default policy.

This blueprint introduces additional functionality that allows
the lock to be used by users (to prevent accidental changes to
an instance for example), but also allows the lock to taken
by an administrator with appropriate privileges such that it
overrides any lock held by the user (for example to block
actions on a rouge instance)

The change is implemented by adding a record of the tenant
that takes the lock, which also provides an audit capability.

Aside from recording the id of the tenant the schematics of
locking an instance remain the same and are protected by
the existing policy

When unlocking an instance an additional check is made to see
if the lock is held by the owner of the instance. If it isn't
then an additional check is made against the unlock_override policy

This allows the lock and unlock policy to be changes as follows:

"compute_extension:admin_actions:lock": "rule:admin_or_owner",
"compute_extension:admin_actions:unlock": "rule:admin_or_owner",
"compute_extension:admin_actions:unlock_override": "rule:admin_api",

Change-Id: I455cbbbd3101377d431efd70d7848d96573b66ae

Just some preliminary comments.
I understand the logic here is to update a configuration file locally, and then upload it to the target HA proxy VM.

This is not extremely concerning at the moment, but probably not the model we want to have in the long run (also because of the paramiko dependency which I would avoid if we could keep using AMPQ as the message bus)

Anyway, I think you already went through design details on monday. As I'm not up to date, I will wait for your comments."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

So right now, it seems like this would only work for load balancer VMs that are directly reachable via IP from the host running the service agent?  Eugene (I think) had talked about also being able to hope into a namespace used by DHCP or L3 to be able to reach private LB?  

Also, I was under the impression that this code would be spinning up LB VMs on demand, but I don't see any code to do that.  Creating the LB VMs on demand seems pretty important, otherwise people have to manually provision the pool and monitor it."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Cool! Finally we can have running LbaaS code! Thank you for your hard works.
I didn't reviews the code yet, however I wanna run this patch.
Could you share the instruction to test this patch?
devstack patch is very helpful.

Thanks
Nachi"}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
The change implements driver for HAProxy loadbalancer

Features:
 - HAProxy VM booting from predefined image
 - Protocols: HTTP, TCP
 - LB algorithms: round-robin, least-connections, hash-source, hash-uri
 - Session persistence: source ip, http cookie, application cookie
 - Health monitoring: TCP, HTTP, HTTPS (Note: HAProxy config allows only one health monitor per pool)
 - Stats retrieval per pools, members

Implements: blueprint lbaas-haproxy-driver
Change-Id: Iebdf1ed6a7209105503288faf802a94dc841392e

"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-02-07 16:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Purely from an implementation POV... I am skeptical about the idea of Cinder running smbd directly.  Shouldn't it be using init scripts/service/systemctl/etc., to do that?

I think it will conflict with a distro-configured Samba server, and it will also probably break on distros using SELinux.

I think, ideally, it would modify smb.conf to create CIFS shares and reload the service, which would be more similar to how it controls NFS via "exportfs".  (It doesn't appear to ever touch the NFS server.)'}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-11 18:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Good point. Thanks Eric, for pointing it out. Working on it.'}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-18 14:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-18 14:15:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

LVM driver is deferred as of now. Will submit it as a separate patch.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-18 15:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-02-20 03:20:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

So all in all Rushi this turned out pretty well and it's exactly what I asked for in terms of the design etc.

I am wondering though:  With LVM taken out the only device this entire service supports is NetApp, is that correct?  Seems like a pretty big addition to Cinder for what's basically a NetApp driver, but maybe I'm missing something.

The other thing I don't quite understand is if there's no integration with Nova and the end user is still expected to do log on to the VM and perform the mounts etc, why not just give them access to a NetApp management app and be done with it?

I also have some concerns around the fact that since it currently only appears to support NetApp devices, there's no way to do any testing in the OpenStack testing infrastructure.  How do we keep this updated and tested if we were to release it as it is now?

I still have strong feelings about Shared Network storage in  the OpenStack BlockStorage service but I'm ignoring that here."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2013-02-20 05:55:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-20 09:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@jgriffith:

Regarding your first question, I think you and bswartz had a discussion and we're going to bring this thing (extension for LVM drivers) up in the Cinder meeting today.

Regarding support/integration for this feature in other OpenStack projects, we have it timeframed for Havana release, which would include integration from Nova as well as some additions to Quantum. We are not thinking about only providing support for NetApp based NAS storage.

Yeah, currently it appears as though this ~4K submission is only favouring NetApp storage, but we're definitely putting efforts to push in the polished version of Linux based NAS drivers."}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-20 12:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-02-20 12:39:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Increased code coverage of cinder.shares.api to 93% and cinder.shares.driver to 77%. Majority of the left out lines in shares.driver.py are NotImplementedError and I am not sure I should write tests for it (its kinda abstract base class)'}, {'account_id': 428, 'date': '2013-02-20 12:43:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Rushi, thanks - looks great.

John Griffith, et al - I'd like to point out the egg:chicken, chicken:egg aspect of things here.  As Rushi points out we're working on a reference LVM based driver that should provide a generalized solution.  But since this represents the advent of a shared file system capability, we wouldn't expect to see other vendor oriented driver implementations yet.

On the topic of having instances absorb mounts / shares vended to them, that's something we've targeted as a Havana activity.  The topic of a instance resident agent (or some similar mechanism) has been discussed, but there'd been little priority to solving a hypothetical problem (the shared file system feature didn't exist yet).  Again, a sort of predestination paradox...  In our opinion the resolution to this shouldn't be a NetApp (or other solution) specific management application, but a community conceived / supported mechanism.  There are other applications for an optional client resident agent and this is something that ought be agreed upon across project boundaries.  We'd planned on proposing design summit track sessions on the topic."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-20 13:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21290/5/check/gate-cinder-python26/2349 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21290/5/check/gate-cinder-python27/2364 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21290/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/4480 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21290/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/9006 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-02-20 17:19:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-02-21 16:28:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not merge

Feature freeze until H1 opens up'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-23 17:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Gave my take on the list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-February/005955.html'}, {'account_id': 6925, 'date': '2013-02-26 04:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It seems there are two separate things discussed
1) filer management - an API for managing filers such as NetApp
2) guest OS access to file systems

#1) Filers are different from block and even different from object file systems.  If you want to standardize the management of filers, why not create a separate project & associated service?  The trouble with adding another abstraction to cinder is that we add complexity and risk breaking the abstraction.  To take it to extremes, why not have swift or even glance in the same cinder project too?  What about nova and quantum while we're at it?  KISS - think like unix do one thing well.  If this was a separate project this would be a very different discussion.
2) Someone else suggested that cloud-init could be used to mount file systems at first boot.  Of course, we should get cloud-init under a different license as gpl can be a barrier for many enterprises even if it is silly.  Clearly CIFS and NFS would be of interest - but what about other cluster file systems?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add NAS features as a separate service

This commit adds the 'shares' service to Cinder. Responding
to the concerns from the community, the code is significantly
refactored to have a minimal impact on the existing code.

This feature adds support for file-based storage in Cinder:
the NFS and CIFS. Along with shares API, this commit implements
a NetApp specific driver for CIFS and NFS access. The LVM driver
implementing same functionality will land in future.

Implements blueprint cinder-protocol-enhancements

Change-Id: I37cb542d13002687ecbfe7c7f3e0e7eb7cecbc03

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-14 12:20:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I feel like there are a number of failure conditions that make me nervous about this at this stage of the game.

First off, Accept-Language isn't a single value, it's weighted range: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.4 because the intent is that it's negotiation with the server.

Secondly, we need a test battery that goes after this pretty aggressively, because I can see how so many things could slip up. Maybe a new tempest battery.

If this was milestone-1 I'd be confident that we would flesh out all the edge conditions by release, but this late in the cycle, I'm less confident, and it makes me nervous, as this is going to impact everything if it's wrong.

I'm a -1, but I'm leaving this as a 0 because I'd really like other folks to look at it, and at this stage of g-3 if I -1 it will be completely ignored given the size of the review queue."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-14 22:24:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Do not merge

I agree with Sean on this one.  It's very late in the release cycle.  We need to be extremely cautious and conservative with changes that affect all of the API.  So, with that said I think this should wait for Havana."}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I completely understand the caution. Moving this back to H would give me more time to work out the current localization shortcomings that I had to work around in this change as well.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-31 23:01:13.000000000', 'message': 'support API message localization

To delay message translation until we can make a determination
of which locale to localize the message to, we can override
the _() localization function to return a Message object
that can act like a string until it needs to be localized
and written to some output

bp user-locale-api

Change-Id: I252f77d71a21640d1c7e775378da1e59b11e4974
'}, {'created': '2013-02-01 19:53:07.000000000', 'message': 'support API message localization

To delay message translation until we can make a determination
of which locale to localize the message to, we can override
the _() localization function to return a Message object
that can act like a string until it needs to be localized
and written to some output

commit_message:
support API message localization

To delay message translation until we can make a determination
of which locale to localize the message to, we can override
the _() localization function to return a Message object
that can act like a string until it needs to be localized
and written to some output

bp user-locale-api

Change-Id: I252f77d71a21640d1c7e775378da1e59b11e4974

commit_message:
Adds landing page for docs.openstack.org/ops

For new Operations Guide.

Patchset adds tracking for outbound links.
Patchset reverts changes to www/index.html.
Patchset flips the columns to avoid overlap.
Patchset adds .pdf download, lulu blue button, and explains mobi.
Patchset changes links to profile page rather than direct download.
Patchset emphasizes the membership is free.
Patchset adds DOCTYPE header for IE compatibility.
Patchset reverts to direct download and renames the PDF file for
consistency.
Patchset adds front and back covers to the PDF.

Change-Id: I096efd41cf45df03cf01bf5115172f80179b3800

"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-28 01:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Minor typo: "etag: "etagoftheobjectsegment" should be "etag": "etagoftheobjectsegment"

The container stats are a bit weird because the manifest object sizes are a bit weird. I'll try to explain. It's due to the manifest object contents having the last_modified info stored, but that info isn't returned when doing a multipart-manifest=get so the sizes don't match up.

I had a container with 4 items in it. 2 were real objects, 4 and 5 bytes. 2 were manifest objects. In the listing they showed 13 bytes each, which is right, that's the size of the concatenated segments they point to. HEADing each with multipart-manifest=get showed each using 282 bytes. However, they were really using 540 bytes each due to the hidden last_modified info stored. So the overall X-Container-Bytes-Used was 4+5+540+540 = 1089 instead of the 4+5+282+282 = 573 I expected as a user.

I'm not sure why the last_modified info is saved, tbh. Is that to know what last-modified value to give the overall object? If it's needed, probably best to include it in the multipart-manifest=get contents so the sizes all match up.'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-02-28 17:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-28 18:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 23:15:38.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent reboot of rescued instance.

Do not allow rebooting an instance in the RESCUED state.  This will
revert the instance back into an ACTIVE state, which may still be
broken.  Require an explicit unrescue, instead.

Fix bug 1126163.

Change-Id: I144163666767923e3beb0a82e687066d1f3a0441
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent reboot of rescued instance.

Do not allow rebooting an instance in the RESCUED state.  This will
revert the instance back into an ACTIVE state, which may still be
broken.  Require an explicit unrescue, instead.

Fix bug 1126163.

Change-Id: I144163666767923e3beb0a82e687066d1f3a0441

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-05 01:46:20.000000000', 'message': "Bump instance updated_at on network change.

Update add-fixed-ip and remove-fixed-ip code paths to update the
updated_at field of the instance, since from the user's perspective
through the API, they have made a change to the instance's
configuration.  In that case, it makes sense to expect that the
updated_at field gets changed.

Fix bug 1143466.

Change-Id: Icfd7d0b1b556795d94a22c1719727f8c9fc744f0
"}]
commit_message:
Bump instance updated_at on network change.

Update add-fixed-ip and remove-fixed-ip code paths to update the
updated_at field of the instance, since from the user's perspective
through the API, they have made a change to the instance's
configuration.  In that case, it makes sense to expect that the
updated_at field gets changed.

Fix bug 1143466.

Change-Id: Icfd7d0b1b556795d94a22c1719727f8c9fc744f0

commit_message:
Catching InstanceNotFound exception during reboot instance

If the instance is deleted during reboot(most of soft reboot), an
InstanceNotFound exception may be raised when update instance info to DB,
and the instance may become running deleted, so catching the exception and
logging it.
This commit is a supplement of bug #1111213, which may result in the instance
becomes running deleted, when deleting an instance after soft reboot.

Change-Id: I3e8df109d431040c64e87f16ca84ff5b62dde898

commit_message:
update tests/__init__.py to verify openssl version

keystone uses `openssl cms` which does not exist before openssl 1.0.0,
older systems and versions of OS X ship with 0.9.8

Change-Id: I30d58e8d60796536d5d2ed632d32674f216647c3

commit_message:
Return proper error messages while disassociating floating IP

Currently, when a floating IP is not associated with an instance, and if we try
to disassociate it, a response likes "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found" will be returned,
it is not proper, so change it to "HTTP/1.1 422 Unprocessable Entity" with body
likes '{"computeFault": {"message": "Floating ip 172.24.4.225 is not associated
with instance a33857af-b18b-4b88-a5cc-7d84c7fd41c8.", "code": 422}}'.

Fixes bug: #1129719

Change-Id: I18194ccf59edb5eb2bcd52a65f38d5632fef95d3

commit_message:
Adding test_security_group_rules_create_with_invalid_port_range

A negative test which verifies that a Security Group rule creation
with invalid port range fails.

In addition, fixing few pep8's identation errors.

Change-Id: I092201fb33392a28de88c68e5cf4b86e2e748a84

commit_message:
Run some APIv1 tests on different backends

This is a first change towards implementing bug #1131638. It clears a lot of
stuff in the various DB mocking stuff, and I plan to do more after.

In the same process, this implements a unit test and a fix for bug #1138137

Change-Id: I36a6741393455c764913e0388d73d834db06da8c
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Fixes linuxbridge agent downs with tap device deletion timing issue

Fixes bug 1136264

Add try/except in deamon loop for preventing agent broken down by
unhandled exception.

commit_message:
quantum security_group driver queries db regression

The following commit 1c6cc18 removed the populate_security_groups()
method in nova/compute/api.py which causes nova-api to check against the
database if a security group exists.

Fixes bug 1145426

Change-Id: I35a6003ac4c16df364302cf90f701ed977f54946

https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1140324"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-03-04 09:09:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I disagree with Steve's comments; if we are in the middle of creating an instance and it returns the status DELETED, that absolutely *is* unexpected and we should definitely raise an exception and *not* keep trying forever (return False) in the hope that it will eventually become ACTIVE.

commit_message:
Move instance polling into check_active()

Don't poll for the instance status in handle_create(). Allow
Resource.create() to poll the resource using check_active().

Change-Id: I13a8fefcef6594d014e7e5a3131f9342521e367d
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-03-04 06:02:26.000000000', 'message': 'Use oslo logging setup.

The one reason we kept our own version was because of the qpid
logging that is quite useful. But this is now easily done via
the "default_log_levels" option.

I have setup the api servers with:
 ampqlib,qpid.messaging,keystone,eventlet
and the engine with:
 ampqlib,qpid.messaging,keystone,eventlet,sqlalchemy

bug: 1143629
Change-Id: I04eeab469ab59da550e08188d53b2cfbb576c04d
Signed-off-by: Angus Salkeld <asalkeld@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use oslo logging setup.

The one reason we kept our own version was because of the qpid
logging that is quite useful. But this is now easily done via
the "default_log_levels" option.

I have setup the api servers with:
 ampqlib,qpid.messaging,keystone,eventlet
and the engine with:
 ampqlib,qpid.messaging,keystone,eventlet,sqlalchemy

bug: 1143629
Change-Id: I04eeab469ab59da550e08188d53b2cfbb576c04d
Signed-off-by: Angus Salkeld <asalkeld@redhat.com>

box.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 17:39:09.000000000', 'message': 'Modify N802 rule output and hacking.py to match the code

The git standard is 50 characters for the commit summary followed by
a 72 character maximum for the commit body.  This is based upon the
need to limit commit message summaries for posting to a mailing list.
At some point, it appears the rule was changed to allow a proper
length commit message.

This patch changes the hacking.rst docs and hacking.py N802 error to
indicate the actual limit is 72 characters rather then 50 characters.

Change-Id: I47f1f1f1007f5744bf1fef419df7e033803b4a53
Fixes: Bug #1144840
'}, {'created': '2013-03-04 20:22:50.000000000', 'message': 'docs should indicate proper git commit limit

The nova gate should recommend 50 characters or less for a git commit
but actually enforce 72 characters.

This patch changes the hacking.rst docs to indicate the actual limit
is 72 characters rather then 50 characters.

Change-Id: I47f1f1f1007f5744bf1fef419df7e033803b4a53
Fixes: Bug #1144840
'}, {'created': '2013-03-04 20:24:02.000000000', 'message': 'docs should indicate proper git commit limit

The nova gate should recommend 50 characters or less for a git commit
but actually enforce 72 characters.

This patch changes the hacking.rst docs to indicate the actual limit
is 72 characters rather then 50 characters.

Change-Id: I47f1f1f1007f5744bf1fef419df7e033803b4a53
Fixes: Bug #1144840
'}]
commit_message:
docs should indicate proper git commit limit

The nova gate should recommend 50 characters or less for a git commit
but actually enforce 72 characters.

This patch changes the hacking.rst docs to indicate the actual limit
is 72 characters rather then 50 characters.

Change-Id: I47f1f1f1007f5744bf1fef419df7e033803b4a53
Fixes: Bug #1144840

I haven't been able to find any good documentation on ldap.controls.SimplePagedResultsControl ... what did you use when writing this?"}, {'account_id': 6734, 'date': '2013-01-25 06:54:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Some explanation
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2696

Documentation:
http://www.python-ldap.org/doc/html/ldap-controls.html#ldap.controls.SimplePagedResultsControl

Example code using paging:
http://www.novell.com/coolsolutions/tip/18274.html'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-01-25 17:20:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Regarding the documentation you pointed to, http://www.python-ldap.org/doc/html/ldap-controls.html#ldap.controls.SimplePagedResultsControl points to what looks like a newer version of the API, so I'd just be guessing when reviewing this change. I say it looks like a newer version because the doc has ldap.controls.libldap.SimplePagedResultsControl whereas this code uses ldap.controls.SimplePagedResultsControl and the interfaces are different. I also tried installing Ubuntu 12.04 python-ldap-docs but those were useless."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-01 02:01:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It was my understanding that using paged queries in LDAP maintains state, and that we will end up with a lot of dangling connections.  I realize that they are the only option for paged results, but I think that they might bring an LDAP server to its knees over time, and that would be bad."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-04 16:47:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

code looks good, but i'm curious about the concerns above"}, {'account_id': 6734, 'date': '2013-02-06 14:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The state is maintained on memory on the LDAP server. We are using this method for querying Active Directory users (+48K) in different other services and there was no major issue.
Unfortunately it is the only way to retrieve more than 1000 entries on AD.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-06 16:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
enable test_servers_negative

this was disabled when we were seeing flakey fails during Folsom
release, however all but one of these tests current pass. And the
failure is a new nova bug. Pushing to CI to verify that bug on both
databases before providing the fixes to nova (of which there will
be at least 2)

fix xml clients for negative tests

the xml clients were failing additional tests because the clients
didn't support all the features as the json tests. This enables
security_groups and networks in the xml client for create.

It also skips the test_create_numeric_server_name as that can't be
tested in xml, it always turns it into a string.

Fixes bug #1046870

Change-Id: I8a3a0bef9b1d134da369242a0cf14c3dcb61c6de

commit_message:
disable swift by default

the swift configuration currently in devstack doesn't work on blank
environments. Turn off all the swift services for now until fixes
are available.

Change-Id: I6881abd8fc553b6d699cbbc30b70299c8dfb3b5a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-27 18:45:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix errant XHR request happening on every page

The check of the jquery selector by name will always return a
non-null object even if the object does not exist on the page,
the check needs to make sure the object returned doesn't
contain any items.

Change-Id: I51367547a37a2ee72ed300853d35d3cc6d89df7d
Fixes: bug #1132588
"}]
commit_message:
Fix errant XHR request happening on every page

The check of the jquery selector by name will always return a
non-null object even if the object does not exist on the page,
the check needs to make sure the object returned doesn't
contain any items.

Change-Id: I51367547a37a2ee72ed300853d35d3cc6d89df7d
Fixes: bug #1132588

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 15:39:25.000000000', 'message': 'heat clients : Make heat-boto rollback disabled by default

The boto library always sends the DisableRollback parameter,
defaulted to False, which is the opposite of the engine
default now, so we have to set DisableRollback to True in
the boto client wrapper

ref bug 1131303

Change-Id: I4acbba7b37f24cb1a874292ff2323ae24b630edf
'}, {'created': '2013-03-04 20:49:40.000000000', 'message': 'heat clients : Make heat-boto rollback disabled by default

The boto library always sends the DisableRollback parameter,
defaulted to False, which is the opposite of the engine
default now, so we have to set DisableRollback to True in
the boto client wrapper

ref bug 1131303

Change-Id: I4acbba7b37f24cb1a874292ff2323ae24b630edf
'}]
commit_message:
heat clients : Make heat-boto rollback disabled by default

The boto library always sends the DisableRollback parameter,
defaulted to False, which is the opposite of the engine
default now, so we have to set DisableRollback to True in
the boto client wrapper

ref bug 1131303

Change-Id: I4acbba7b37f24cb1a874292ff2323ae24b630edf

commit_message:
Pin pep8 to 1.3.3

Part of making pep8 version standard across all openstack
projects.

Fixes LP: #1143569

Change-Id: Iefc923123243df161ed72888c1651a622afbda04
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-26 15:24:16.000000000', 'message': "fix postgresql drop race

when running under testr there is a chance that we enter
reset_databases for the postgresql tests at the same time for both
general and baremetal tests. In this case the pg admin commands
could fail, as pg gets really strict about having 2 users trying
to do admin commands at the same time on a single database (in
this case the magic template1 db, that we need to use because
you can't drop the db you are currently on.)

Solve this by adding some retry logic. It would also be good to
figure out from pg experts if there is a better way to handle this.

Change-Id: I31555ef5aae27f31daf7cbbae61072a8d7deb255

you can't drop the db you are currently on.)

Solve this by adding some retry logic. It would also be good to
figure out from pg experts if there is a better way to handle this.
Also, make sure the retry logic doesn't loop forever.

commit_message:
fix postgresql drop race

when running under testr there is a chance that we enter
reset_databases for the postgresql tests at the same time for both
general and baremetal tests. In this case the pg admin commands
could fail, as pg gets really strict about having 2 users trying
to do admin commands at the same time on a single database (in
this case the magic template1 db, that we need to use because
you can't drop the db you are currently on.)

Solve this by breaking out the postgresql reset case into a
seperate function and using @lockutils on it.

Change-Id: I31555ef5aae27f31daf7cbbae61072a8d7deb255

commit_message:
Avoid sending names longer than 40 character to NVP

Bug 1130192

NVP limits for name lenghts are much shorter than Quantum's.
The quantum name is truncated before dispatching the NVP API operation.

Change-Id: Idee568756a0df991003f59d498846ac9ff7fe095

commit_message:
Standardize the coverage initializations.

Now when we measure coverage repeatedly, the coverage data of
nova-api is accumulated but the ones of other nova services are
reset each time.
This is due to create new "coverage" class each time
"_start_coverage_telnet" method is executed.

This patch limits creating "coverage" class the first time
the method is executed.

Fixes bug 1122720

Change-Id: Ia900c96113bee65362ccb7c4c1975535d814d835

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-15 20:12:38.000000000', 'message': "Push 'Error' result from event to instance action.

Currently a failed event stores an 'Error' result but in order to see
which actions have failed it would require grabbing each one through the
api to see the events.  This patch adds 'Error' to the message field of
the instance action so that any actions with failures can be seen from
the initial listing of actions on an instance.

Change-Id: Ieeb798c47211ab00fe5b767dc1f18a665549ba01
"}]
commit_message:
Push 'Error' result from event to instance action.

Currently a failed event stores an 'Error' result but in order to see
which actions have failed it would require grabbing each one through the
api to see the events.  This patch adds 'Error' to the message field of
the instance action so that any actions with failures can be seen from
the initial listing of actions on an instance.

Change-Id: Ieeb798c47211ab00fe5b767dc1f18a665549ba01

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-04 19:00:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hm, so the currently-on-master get_more_nodes() has the property that it'll eventually yield every other disk in the cluster. However, this get_more_nodes lacks that property.

I'm not sure yet how much of a problem this is for small clusters; I need some time to think it over / run experiments.

For large clusters, though, this looks good."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-03-04 19:11:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

With a small cluster if you use a big enough ring power it should have the all-disks property just because of how many times those disks are going to be on the ring. It's when you get a large cluster and each device isn't on the ring as much that you'll have a chance to miss some devices completely -- which shouldn't be that big of a deal since the cluster's so big."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-04 19:28:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I'm more worried about weird stripeyness in the ring where the drive count is a multiple of (part_power - 16) and there hasn't been a ton of rebalancing.

I'm hacking up a script to try out a few scenarios and see if it's actually a problem."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-04 20:00:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Looks like commit a4ebc46 beat the stripeyness out of the ring builder. Before that, it was pretty easy to get patterns in your _replica2part2dev, but now it's not, so the patterns I was worried about possibly somehow leading to problems in get_more_nodes() don't even exist.

Ship it!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-04 20:00:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 08:54:16.000000000', 'message': 'Updated get_more_nodes algorithm

The handoff nodes will try to be in zones other than the primary
zones, will take into account the device weights, and will usually
keep the same sequences of handoffs even with ring changes.

On a real ring test the old get_more_nodes placed data mostly evenly
across zones, which is a problem for differently weighted zones. But
the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed closer to what the zone weights were
and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.24% with
90.58% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 10.71%.

Change-Id: Iffb133a22db69074acaa2b90854cbfa92e4c2b9e
'}]
commit_message:
Updated get_more_nodes algorithm

The handoff nodes will try to be in zones other than the primary
zones, will take into account the device weights, and will usually
keep the same sequences of handoffs even with ring changes.

On a real ring test the old get_more_nodes placed data mostly evenly
across zones, which is a problem for differently weighted zones. But
the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed closer to what the zone weights were
and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.24% with
90.58% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 10.71%.

Change-Id: Iffb133a22db69074acaa2b90854cbfa92e4c2b9e

commit_message:
heat clients : Change --disable-rollback to --enable-rollback

Since the engine default is now rollback disabled, flip this
switch so the user can opt-in to rollback functionality via
the --enable-rollback cli option to heat-cfn/heat-boto

ref bug 1131303

Change-Id: I3965de9a2beb510d5623d0c7cd8ff3aea9d4364a

commit_message:
heat engine : Disable stack rollback by default

Until the event-persistence BP is implemented, we should
disable stack rollback by default and make it opt-in.

fixes bug 1131303

Change-Id: I101e108c3959c4b7b4cfc68449ba2b989b157626

commit_message:
Change --disable-rollback option to --enable-rollback

Due to bug 1131303, the engine default is changing to disable
rollback by default, so we instead need an option to allow
users to enable this functionality

fixes bug 1144630

Change-Id: I509e616e20a3e4750ffcefe6e72c52e5f60445bc

commit_message:
Fixes oslo-config update for deprecated_group

Fixes bug: 1140310

The oslo-config dependency referenced in pip-requires should be updated to
the latest version to include support for "deprecated_group".
This is needed to move specific driver options from the DEFAULT group w/o
losing backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I5d18a5ee704a1f781c8acd6f903b0e3ca07bc070

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-01 15:41:41.000000000', 'message': "Only use statsd if configured.

Fixes bug 1116542.

Wrap any references to statsd's methods in a check for the statsd
object, since it will be None and thus evaluate False when not
configured.

Change-Id: Ia07afd9dde6a30b3f7bdcb2bc336494d28e714a3
"}]
commit_message:
Only use statsd if configured.

Fixes bug 1116542.

Wrap any references to statsd's methods in a check for the statsd
object, since it will be None and thus evaluate False when not
configured.

Change-Id: Ia07afd9dde6a30b3f7bdcb2bc336494d28e714a3

commit_message:
Exclude tests when installing ceilometer

Dont include the tests directory when installing
ceilometer as they might conflict with other
poorly installed packages on the users systems.

Fixes LP: #1102110

Signed-off-by Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

Change-Id: Ia8b0477af72b30dcf54b4751a51bbb460a7a90f4

commit_message:
Simple implementation of DNSMasq backend

The logic is quite simple. All dns zones are stored in separate files.
They are eventually merged into one flat dns zone.
And this file (or any separate zone) should be specified in dnsmasq config file (--addn-hosts=).
Update is also simple, all you need is to send a SIGHUP to dnsmasq to force re-read of the file.

Change-Id: Id634ca2843fd02a8406913881d4989c7c2112249

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-02 00:58:54.000000000', 'message': "Compute manager should remove dead resources

While most hypervisors return a single - and constant - value from
driver.get_available_nodes, baremetal does not. When a node is deleted
from the baremetal database, it is no longer returned from
driver.get_available_nodes. However, Nova's compute_node record is not
directly updated.

the dead node and remove it from compute.

This in turn allows the ServiceGroup API to properly update the
servicegroup when a baremetal node is no longer in service.

commit_message:
Compute manager should remove dead resources

While most hypervisors return a single - and constant - value from
driver.get_available_nodes, baremetal does not. When a node is deleted
from the baremetal database, it is no longer returned from
driver.get_available_nodes. However, Nova's compute_node record is not
directly updated.

This patch allows Compute Manager to detect missing nodes within
update_available_resources. It then invokes resource_tracker to update
the dead node and remove it from compute.

This in turn allows the ServiceGroup API to properly update the
servicegroup when a baremetal node is no longer in service.

Fixes bug 1138184

Change-Id: Icfff3f8e3099668806633a6a58a152b32ec8b49b

[{'created': '2013-02-27 21:37:36.000000000', 'message': "Fallback coverage backdoor telnet connection to lo

This commit adds a fallback condition for the telnet connection.
If trying to establish a connection to the backdoor fails with
CONNREFUSED the extension will then try to connect to the same
port on the lo device. Eventlet backdoors currently open on the
lo interface and this is to cover the common (and CI) use case
where the hostname doesn't resolve to 127.0.0.1.

Using the fallback was done to avoid adding a new config option
to specify that the hostname that is in the DB for the service
doesn't resolve to the lo device, and that the extension should
use just use localhost.

Change-Id: I0321db68cbccf0cddf13d91a77dfb744bb456d87

commit_message:
Fallback coverage backdoor telnet connection to lo

This commit adds a fallback condition for the telnet connection.
If trying to establish a connection to the backdoor fails with
ECONNREFUSED the extension will then try to connect to the same
port on the lo device. Eventlet backdoors currently open on the
lo interface and this is to cover the common (and CI) use case
where the hostname doesn't resolve to 127.0.0.1.

Using the fallback was done to avoid adding a new config option
to specify that the hostname that is in the DB for the service
doesn't resolve to the lo device, and that the extension should
use just use localhost.

Change-Id: I0321db68cbccf0cddf13d91a77dfb744bb456d87
