[{'created': '2013-02-27 16:07:10.000000000', 'message': 'Adds retry on upload_vhd in xapi glance plugin

Add a retry in the xapi glance plugin to handle transient issues
when uploading the vhd.

An example issue we're seeing is a connection timeout:

['XENAPI_PLUGIN_FAILURE', 'upload_vhd', 'error',
		"(110, 'Connection timed out')"]

To work around transient issues such as a connection timeout, I think
the glance plugin should retry the upload a small number of times
before outright failing.

commit_message:
Adds retry on upload_vhd for xapi glance plugin

Add a retry for the xapi glance plugin to handle transient issues
when uploading the vhd.

An example issue we're seeing is a connection timeout:

['XENAPI_PLUGIN_FAILURE', 'upload_vhd', 'error',
		"(110, 'Connection timed out')"]

To work around transient issues such as a connection timeout, we
should retry based on glance_num_retries before outright failing.

Change-Id: Ice6fdd3dd39ef40e5997d69209aaafa66bff5d6e
Fixes: bug #1134493

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-04 15:31:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes confirm migrate issue during "nova migrate"

This issue is caused by deleting the non-existed metadata with prefix "old_"
in function confirm_resize().

Based on current implement, when calling "nova migrate <server>" with
allow_resize_to_same_host=true and there is only one host, No metadata with
prefix 'old_' will be saved. But on calling "resize-confirm", confirm_resize()
will try to delete both the metadata with prefix 'old_' and 'new_ '. Then user
will run into exception which said: "KeyError: 'old_instance_type_memory_mb'"

So this fix is about to make sure the metadata with prefix "old_" will be
savid in _finish_resize() to avoid the exception.

Fixes Bug: 1136768

Change-Id: Ia05807a1395135491ceeb2595a0dd0b7147eb382
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes confirm migrate issue during "nova migrate"

This issue is caused by deleting the non-existed metadata with prefix "old_"
in function confirm_resize().

Based on current implement, when calling "nova migrate <server>" with
allow_resize_to_same_host=true and there is only one host, No metadata with
prefix 'old_' will be saved. But on calling "resize-confirm", confirm_resize()
will try to delete both the metadata with prefix 'old_' and 'new_ '. Then user
will run into exception which said: "KeyError: 'old_instance_type_memory_mb'"

So this fix is about to make sure the metadata with prefix "old_" will be
savid in _finish_resize() to avoid the exception.

Fixes Bug: 1136768

Change-Id: Ia05807a1395135491ceeb2595a0dd0b7147eb382

commit_message:
Decouple the nova notifier from ceilometer code

The move to oslo.config introduced a conflict in the nova notifier
because both nova and ceilometer have copies of the
openstack.common.rpc library and define an option for the AMQP
exchange name for the project. This changeset decouples the notifier
plugin in ceilometer from most of the ceilometer code, to remove that
conflict.

The nova notifier is rewritten to emit a new notification message with
event type `compute.instance.delete.samples` instead of making the old
RPC calls directly to the ceilometer collector, and a notification
listener plugin is provided to convert those messages to sample data.

The notifier implementations are split between the one that worked
in folsom and the one that works in grizzly to maintain backwards
compatibility.

get_hypervisor_inspector() is moved to a location where it can be
imported both by the compute agent manager and the notifier
plugin. The definition of `disabled_compute_pollsters` option is also
moved for the same reason.

The tox configuration is changed to run the nova notifier tests
separately from the other tests, since nose cannot import nova and
ceilometer code in the same process.

bug 1130952

Change-Id: I39ba4564c9c14f09dbdd768d7a83f6940e3942ad
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Don't log a traceback on rpc call timeout.

There are cases where an rpc call is gracefully handled.  The rpc
drivers should just let the caller deal with this and decide whether it
is an error worth logging a traceback over.  Otherwise, we unnecessarily
raise alarm by leaving a mess in the log file.

Fix bug 1137994.

Change-Id: I0e831ddcc43ffea78aae1fb5e46c5037c461b2a1

commit_message:
Refactor error logging

It is hard to grep errors in current log. so in this patch,
I'm updating die function which also writes log for
screen_log_dir/error.log.
In future, we may categolize negative fault by using
this error.log.

Change-Id: I70a8cfe67ed408284f5c88c762c6bb8acb8ecdb2

- http://logs.openstack.org/23396/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/11663 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with the other reviewers that this patch puts us in a situation where the agents are intelligent enough to understand whether they should report state or not, so we might avoid the configuration flags.

To an extent, one might think about even merging back the two classes into one. I understand having a desire for extremely flexible configurations, but since we've not yet committed to a framework with configurable agent managers, I'd rather not have a flag in this version, and add one in the next version, than having a flag in this version and then removing or changing it in the next one."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

I still have the same view as Dan and Alex's view. The only difference with DhcpAgent and DhcpAgentWithStateReport is that the quantum server output a log message about attribute error or not if a plugin does not support the agent extension. I see no difference other than it and there seems to be no need to have an option. The config options dhcp_agent_manager or l3_agent_manager allow users to select a different implementation, but i believe it does not apply to this case."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

lgtm, just two nits.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-03-04 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Prints list-cached dates in isoformat

Converts dates printed by list-cached to a human readable format
(isoformat). It now checks whether the image last_access time is == 0.0
and prints "Not Accessed Yet" if so.

* Updates openstack.common.timeutils
* Fixes bug 1102334

Change-Id: I6f60525d8419d45e6962b936a2661825b606cba2

commit_message:
remove intermediate libvirt downloaded images

* nova/virt/images.py (fetch_to_raw): When converting a downloaded
image to raw, ensure we delete the original download image.
I.E. the .part file.  The regression was introduced in 7c265343.
* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py (test_fetch_raw_image): A new test
for this function which wasn't tested previously.

Conflicts:

	nova/tests/test_libvirt.py
	nova/virt/images.py

Fixes bug: 1125068
Change-Id: Ie6f2cff1a554b8500fd66f0832566ae1b317be40
(cherry picked from commit 1501a4e4f75efb63385a1dadc728c2ef245bf7de)

commit_message:
Incorrect argument in calling post_json

The error is due to change in webtest in which post_json is redefined.
Fix to work with its new definition.

Fixes bug #1138233

Change-Id: I08c131bf50886456f0501d5fa8493e05543c5816

commit_message:
Don't LOG.error on max_depth (by default).

Reverts part of 7b206ad which added an extra LOG.error
statement when max_depth is hit.

This is causing spurious errors to get logged when making
some Nova requests.

Fixes LP Bug #1140133

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-25 23:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Let's say I've got some partition:
 - 3 primary nodes P1, P2, and P3
 - first "normal" handoff node H
 - first replication handoff node RH

Alright, now P3 dies (disk burns down, falls over, and sinks into the swamp).

Then, a PUT happens. The proxy sends copies of the object* to P1, P2, and H. Some time later, the replicator on H copies its stuff over to RH and deletes its local replica of that partition.

Seems like this change would create extra replicator activity in the case of failed disks. Either that or I've misunderstood something; that's probably the more likely option.

Thoughts?

* or whatever'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-25 23:27:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's true. The issue seems to be that we want two different things. We want requests to be sent to as distinct as possible handoffs but we (well, maybe just I) want replication handoffs to be very evenly distributed, but very static as well.

Meaning, with replication we don't want to be resending whole partitions of data all over the place if we can avoid it. Little PUT/DELETE handoffs that eventually get back to home base are easy to handle.

Not sure I'm explaining very well, let me know. :)"}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-02-25 23:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The proxy is currently able to look at handoff nodes for files in some failure scenarios.  So this could reduce availability in those cases.  I guess that might be like .0000001% of the time, though.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-25 23:37:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah dangit, I forgot about that. Well, I'm hesitant to change the default handoff algorithm since it seems folks put a lot of work into it. But it really, really sucked this last time we had a bunch of drive failures."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-26 00:06:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

FWIW, the handoff algorithm has been basically the same for a long time. Here's some code from the oldest Git commit:

    yield self.zone2devs[zone][part % len(self.zone2devs[zone])]

And here it is from master (edited for brevity):

    dev = self.tier2devs[tier][(part + i) % len(self.tier2devs[tier])]
    if not dev.get('weight'):
        continue
    yield dev

Here, the variable 'i' starts at 0, and it's just there so you can keep going if the device you find has no weight; it doesn't otherwise affect the selection of handoffs.

The point of all this is that the handoff-selection algorithm hasn't really changed in a long, long time, so if it's got flaws, be fearless. :)"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-26 09:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-26 09:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Okay, back to the one get_more_nodes. Did a lot of testing, profiling, tweaking, etc. to this bugger. At this point I probably have blinders and missed something, so review away!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-26 10:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-25 22:22:59.000000000', 'message': 'Added get_more_nodes_for_replication

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1
'}, {'created': '2013-02-26 09:33:02.000000000', 'message': "Updated get_more_nodes

The handoff nodes will try to be in zones other than the primary
zones, will treat devices as all the same weight (generally not a
problem), and will usually keep the same sequences of handoffs even
with ring changes.

On a real ring test the old get_more_nodes placed data mostly evenly
across zones, which is a problem for differently weighted zones. But
the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed fairly close to what the zone weights
were (really differently weighted devices would've altered this
though) and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.15%
with 90.72% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 6.93%.

I also tried Sam's experimental algorithm but it fared worse. It had
the same evenness across zones that the original had. And the extra
partitions given to each device was 0% to 3.27% with only 33.68% of
the candidate devices getting anything. The worst off device
increased 220% in effective weight.

Speed: This new get_more_nodes gets slower as it progresses through
its generator because it's walking the ring and ends up with more and
more skips before finding something to yield. Because of this, the
new algorithm is capped at ten handoffs by default and then it
reverts to the very fast previous algorithm for the rest of the
handoffs. This should work in practice since so many handoffs from
one generator would mean the cluster is very unhealthy and retaining
balance is probably futile.

I am completely open to even better algorithms here; this is just
what I came up with. Unfortunately, due to company policy I can't
share the production ring I've run tests against, but I'm willing to
rerun the tests with whatever algorithm folks come up with.

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1
"}, {'created': '2013-02-26 23:47:12.000000000', 'message': 'Updated get_more_nodes

The handoff nodes will try to be in zones other than the primary
zones, will take into account the device weights, and will usually
keep the same sequences of handoffs even with ring changes.

On a real ring test the old get_more_nodes placed data mostly evenly
across zones, which is a problem for differently weighted zones. But
the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed fairly close to what the zone weights
were and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.18%
with 90.65% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 8.09%.

This works by creating a very simple and small handoff ring within
the real ring, and placing the devices into the handoff ring
according to their weights. This placement will be the same for the
same set of devices and weights, and will be very similar for small
changes in the set of devices and weights. It does tend to favor
older devices (those with lower ids) but those are the ones least
likely to change.

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1

the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed closer to what the zone weights were
and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.24% with
90.58% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 10.71%.

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1

in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed closer to what the zone weights were

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1

commit_message:
Updated get_more_nodes

The handoff nodes will try to be in zones other than the primary
zones, will take into account the device weights, and will usually
keep the same sequences of handoffs even with ring changes.

On a real ring test the old get_more_nodes placed data mostly evenly
across zones, which is a problem for differently weighted zones. But
the real problem was that the extra partitions given to each device
was 0% to 0.77% with only 46.05% of the candidate devices getting
anything. Some of the devices increased in effective weight over 50%
in the test.

The new get_more_nodes placed closer to what the zone weights were
and the extra partitions given to each device was 0% to 0.24% with
90.58% of the candidate devices getting something. The worst off
device only increased in effective weight by 10.71%.

Change-Id: Ie09774523ed5e6aeed5c862c0152a09343b641b1

commit_message:
Allow for terminating paused/suspended instances

Fixes bug 1139288

Remove the restriction around terminating paused and suspended
instances, as Nova's API supports this transition and it works fine
for Libvirt/KVM.

Change-Id: Ic2fd9bffa63cb1543ee002bed9e8b68df0344da8

commit_message:
test_server_metadata.py - BP add-xml-support

This change partially implements blueprint add-xml-support

Addition of XML support to test_server_metadata.py
Modified servers_client.py to support the following
calls to check for xml response to server metadata API:
list_server_metadata,
set_server_metadata,
update_server_metadata,
get_server_metadata_item,
set_server_metadata_item,
delete_server_metadata_item.

Implement: Blueprint add-xml-support
Change-Id: If88b769022fefc80a933b76057a0481d4bc3fac6

"It barely does what people want it to do, on purpose." -- G. Lange'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-24 01:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-24 01:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/18562/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/2516 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-30 17:14:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I've been thinking about this a bit, and I'm not sure how I feel about the direction this patch is headed.  There are a couple of areas that concern me.

1.  The idea of having fractional replicas is just weird to me.  It will be hard to document, and will probably cause a lot of confusion for a lot of people.  I understand that the upside is a simpler implementation.  I've been trying to think of a better way to represent the idea in the ring, but have come up short.

2.  This patch only is helpful for cases where the number of replicas is determined by the number of global regions that you have, which I think is a bad for most cases.  We need better ways to express the layout of regions rather than it being determined by the number of replicas.

Which leads me to my current thinking that perhaps a better route might be:

1.  Make the ring easier to plugin
2.  Start work on a new ring structure that can better support global cluster, which could still be based off the current ring

I like this idea, because it would allow us to experiment pretty easily, even possibly with several implementations before settling on what a globally distributed ring should look right, without having to muck up the current ring.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-30 18:44:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

1) I think this explanation is pretty straight-forward and is not confusing:

 A fractional replica count is for the whole ring, not for
 any individual partition, and indicates the average number of replicas
 of each partition. For example, a replica count of 3.2 means that 20%
 of partitions have 4 replicas and 80% have 3 replicas.

And in case it's misunderstood that rings would normally start out and live their entire lives with a single integer replica cout, that could be added to documentation and/or usage messages.

Compared to explaining to people what a "part power" is and how it can never change, explaining this is a walk in the park.

2) I think this would be more accurately phrased, "This patch is only useful when an operator wants to move an existing cluster's ring from one replica count to another, which is fine for some cases."  I don't believe this patch says anything about determining regions from replica counts.  Just as an operator may want, say, 2 regions with 2 replicas each, an operator might want 4 regions with only 3 replicas total.  Both will be supported configurations.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-31 19:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Clay and I had a rather long discussion in IRC about it.  I'm not totally against the ability to change the number of partitions, in general.

By stating that it is a "prerequisite for globally distributed clusters" makes it sound like this is one of the main enablers of such, and probably what causes a lot of confusion/worry.

I still think having fractional numbers of partitions is a bit awkward.  If there is no other way, then so be it, but I bring it up mainly to solicit ideas from others.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-31 19:27:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Adding to the discussion:

There are two assumptions that I made when writing this code.

1. operators may want to change their replica counts, either up or down

2. if you jump from N replicas to N+1 in one step, and you have a lot of data, then replication will destroy your cluster's performance.

Fractional replicas is just something I came up with to let the user move gradually between N replicas and N+1. I'm sure there are plenty of other ways of enabling the same functionality, but I haven't really thought of any good alternatives. (I've thought of plenty of really crappy alternatives, but those aren't worth discussing.)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-31 19:28:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Chuck: this patch is about adjusting the replica count, not the number of partitions. While I'd love to be able to alter the partition count too, the fact that the partition number is part of a thing's filesystem path makes that a pretty daunting task."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-31 23:11:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Doh, sorry Sam.  I meant to say replicas when I said partitions.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:03:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like where this patch is headed. It doesn't add a ton of complexity, it's able to be documented (as darrell said, it's easier than the part_power), and it offers flexibility for all clusters including (but not limited to) ones globally replicated.

My -1 is based on a couple of minor issues:

1) after setting the new fractional replica count, the replica count is reported as an integer.

2) With 4 nodes (SAIO), going from 3.5 to 3 replicas doesn't work (less than 1% changed and therefore bails). Perhaps that check should only bail if the replica count didn't change too."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:27:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

still working on forcing a rebalance after dropping some replica'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Okay, I think I fixed all the problems John saw.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-05 04:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-05 23:06:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-14 17:24:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In my SAIO, with all daemons running, with a default ring setup of part-power==18, replica-count==3, I loaded up a bunch of data.

While tailing all.log, I changed each ring's replica count to 3.5 and rebalanced (see last paste with modified SAIO ~/bin/remakerings).

Obj Replicator Trouble: http://paste.openstack.org/show/qhcWjNCTxIRYlhrD4Pmz/

swift-get-nodes Trouble: http://paste.openstack.org/show/g27S1N9FMceq7kCRezzG/

swift-object-info is okay: http://paste.openstack.org/show/dFo9MQ88F8Coc6uPu7Tv/

Suggested SAIO ~/bin/remakerings for testing this stuff:  http://paste.openstack.org/show/Api70u1cBHQdJHBF0cUb/"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-20 01:05:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Darrell: I can't reproduce the behavior that you're seeing with the object replicator. From the stack trace, my guess is that you had a replicator that was running code without this changeset that was trying to eat a fractional-replica ring.

I base this on two things: first, an IndexError from Ring._get_part_nodes is something that I just don't see happening. I've stared at that code for a good ten minutes trying to spot an off-by-one error or a missing range check or something that would raise an IndexError, and I just can't see anything there. Second, the code lines in the stack trace are from the methods' docstrings, not actual Python code. This makes me think that the interpreter's internal line numbers came from a different file than the one that is currently on disk.

The bin/swift-get-nodes thing is legitimate. I have a fix for that which I'll tack on here as soon as I figure out how the heck to fix up bin/swift-dispersion-report. It also uses Ring.replica_count, and it uses it extensively."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-20 05:28:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Ah, good point... I'll double-check the replicators' running code next go-round."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-20 08:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-21 19:52:41.000000000', 'message': "Make rings' replica counts adjustable.

Example:

$ swift-ring-builder account.builder set_replicas 4
$ swift-ring-builder rebalance

This is a prerequisite for supporting globally-distributed clusters,
as operators of such clusters will probably want at least as many
replicas as they have regions. Therefore, adding a region requires
adding a replica. Similarly, removing a region lets an operator remove
a replica and save some money on disks.

In order to not hose clusters with lots of data, swift-ring-builder
now allows for setting of fractional replicas. Thus, one can gradually
increase the replica count at a rate that does not adversely affect
cluster performance.

Example:

$ swift-ring-builder object.builder set_replicas 3.01
$ swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance
<distribute rings and wait>

$ swift-ring-builder object.builder set_replicas 3.02
$ swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance
<distribute rings and wait>...

Obviously, fractional replicas are nonsensical for a single
partition. A fractional replica count is for the whole ring, not for
any individual partition, and indicates the average number of replicas
of each partition. For example, a replica count of 3.2 means that 20%
of partitions have 4 replicas and 80% have 3 replicas.

Changes do not take effect until after the ring is rebalanced. Thus,
if you mean to go from 3 replicas to 3.01 but you accidentally type
2.01, no data is lost.

Additionally, 'swift-ring-builder X.builder create' can now take a
decimal argument for the number of replicas.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I12b34dacf60350a297a46be493d5d171580243ff

commit_message:
Make rings' replica counts adjustable.

Example:

$ swift-ring-builder account.builder set_replicas 4
$ swift-ring-builder rebalance

This is a prerequisite for supporting globally-distributed clusters,
as operators of such clusters will probably want at least as many
replicas as they have regions. Therefore, adding a region requires
adding a replica. Similarly, removing a region lets an operator remove
a replica and save some money on disks.

In order to not hose clusters with lots of data, swift-ring-builder
now allows for setting of fractional replicas. Thus, one can gradually
increase the replica count at a rate that does not adversely affect
cluster performance.

Example:

$ swift-ring-builder object.builder set_replicas 3.01
$ swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance
<distribute rings and wait>

$ swift-ring-builder object.builder set_replicas 3.02
$ swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance
<distribute rings and wait>...

Obviously, fractional replicas are nonsensical for a single
partition. A fractional replica count is for the whole ring, not for
any individual partition, and indicates the average number of replicas
of each partition. For example, a replica count of 3.2 means that 20%
of partitions have 4 replicas and 80% have 3 replicas.

Changes do not take effect until after the ring is rebalanced. Thus,
if you mean to go from 3 replicas to 3.01 but you accidentally type
2.01, no data is lost.

Additionally, 'swift-ring-builder X.builder create' can now take a
decimal argument for the number of replicas.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I12b34dacf60350a297a46be493d5d171580243ff

commit_message:
Add Service heartbeat driver with RPC.

This patch adds nova.servicegroup.drivers.rpc, a service
heartbeat driver using nova RPC. You can reduce DB updates
with it.

blueprint rpc-based-servicegroup-driver

Change-Id: I4a59bd26d8c53b591bd3c577b2e999a37d3c2090

commit_message:
Fix proposed /etc/ntp.conf

The sample /etc/ntp.conf file as provided at <http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-compute/install/apt/content/osfolubuntu-prerquisite.html> had some confusing or inaccurate information, as well as some incorrect configuration settings.  Updated to be more in line with correct settings and current recommendations from <http://support.ntp.org/bin/view/Support/WebHome>.

Change-Id: I624b805a3cb3663fa985c90b48273e0f84494212

commit_message:
Touch a first-boot.status file:

After running first-boots scripts, both to indicate
that the scripts have completed, and also to record
the exit status.

This is useful for automated testing:
  - tests can wait until first-boot scripts have
    completed before commencing testing
  - tests can abort further testing if first-boot
    scripts have failed.

Change-Id: Idec63de858c15def8c621056232aad45eab225e8

commit_message:
Set where=tests

Many tests assumed to be run from tests, and fails without that if simply
run with 'nosetests', which is handy.

Change-Id: Ief9dba564f809012b38df8533dd5a09e90668517
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Add initial testr support.

This doesn't really do much other that add the needed bits to the repo to
start hacking on testr support in small chunks.

Change-Id: I34fc57fdc7c9ebda8ffa2357a2ef962c7ab41bfa

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-27 22:42:22.000000000', 'message': 'More assertions for test_integration_1

For the boto/test_ec2_instance_run.py test_integration_1 test
add assertions to check that the security group modifications
and public ip association calls actually succeed.

This is to help debug the intermittent bug 1117555 which appears
to be due to the instance sometimes being unreachable via its
public ip.

Change-Id: I8c1ffeee62e1021ecf24f05ac26518ced640c5a1
'}]
commit_message:
More assertions for test_integration_1

For the boto/test_ec2_instance_run.py test_integration_1 test
add assertions to check that the security group modifications
and public ip association calls actually succeed.

This is to help debug the intermittent bug 1117555 which appears
to be due to the instance sometimes being unreachable via its
public ip.

Change-Id: I8c1ffeee62e1021ecf24f05ac26518ced640c5a1

commit_message:
send-counter: fix & test

This fixes the bin/ceilometer-send-counter program that has been broken
after the implementation of multi-publisher.
We also add a test to see if it runs!

This fixes bug #1133226

Change-Id: I922c7a000e942ee28d840f4cd65d13898d6d23a8
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
*WIP* Cells: Sync keypairs to child cells.

Adds the sending of the keypairs for create to child cells.  Also when
deleting a keypair, delete it in the child cells.

Fixes bug 1142901

Change-Id: I4330ba930dcdeb4846f43229fab02632675ab473

that tries to access non existing attributes of xml node:
* find_first_child_named
* extract_text
* find_children_named

Change-Id: I0aff5933fa75e50748e9d0325d898c2f6836fa58
Fixes: bug #1132850
'}]
commit_message:
quantumclient.common.serializer module cleanup

Remove unused methods in quantumclient.common.serializer.XMLDeserializer
that tries to access non existing attributes of xml node:
* find_first_child_named
* extract_text
* find_children_named

Change-Id: I0aff5933fa75e50748e9d0325d898c2f6836fa58
Fixes: bug #1132850

commit_message:
Add ssh port and key based auth to VPD.

This patch adds the ablity to set ssh port, and use key based
authentication for VPD.

This patch adds config options:
    virtual_power_ssh_port: port to ssh to on virtual power host
    virtual_power_host_key: private key file for ssh auth

Note: Key file must be able to be read by user nova is running as.

      This patch switches the default virtual_power_type from 'vbox'
      to 'virsh' to match the most common usage.

Fix Bug 1136010

Change-Id: Id89878d63d26602bb3eacc2a2ce7902d9bd33d61
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Make ComputeManager _running_deleted_instances query by uuid

Reuse existing _get_instances_on_driver method to query driver for
running instances.

Resolves bug 1129519.

Change-Id: I9186b289fadfc4414874b3ba52195e9acfac18b4

commit_message:
Refactor compute manager _get_instances_by_driver

Make the method more efficient by only querying nova-conductor
once. Also limit fallback instance query to host only. This is
in preparation for fixing bug 1129519.

Change-Id: I7de14f1ffda37c14f760f602fd81250d2163b430

commit_message:
Fix unit tests for Instance IP

Don't try to test the IP addresses after the instance has been deleted.

Ref bug #1091497

commit_message:
Fix target host variable from being overwritten

The target host parameter of the compute api evacuate method
is mistakenly overwritten before being used. The result is
that the instance rebuild operation is tried against the
original failed host and will always fail.

Rename locally used variable to a different name and modify
relevant test to prohibit this from happening again.

Resolves bug 1133204.

Change-Id: I517b2dc19d9561723391150105b4943b56dba637

I have approved the change to devstack, so we should be able to re-verify once that has merged.  I agree with the goal of changing this default back to L3NATAgent, but I'd also VERY strongly argue that we should make it so that plugins like OVS view the state report as an optional capability they can take advantage of, not as something that will cause everything to fail if it is not correctly configured. revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-03 19:40:17.000000000', 'message': 'Change the default l3_agent_manager to L3NATAgent

This is a l3-agent version of 349aa3ef3563c019f4d0a98fc30117ae0a6cade3.

The combination of the plugin without agent extension support
and L3NATAgentWithStateReport results in an error:
"AttributeError: No such RPC function 'report_state'".

This patch changes l3_agent_manager to be L3NATAgent instead of
L3NATAgentWithStateReport since all plugins do not support
L3NATAgentWithStateReport and having this as the default breaks
all current deployments that upgrade source without changing
their config files.

Fixes bug 1139726

Change-Id: Ibb5c04c89bfad741ec43a372cbf97445f7b3d76c
'}]
commit_message:
Change the default l3_agent_manager to L3NATAgent

This is a l3-agent version of 349aa3ef3563c019f4d0a98fc30117ae0a6cade3.

The combination of the plugin without agent extension support
and L3NATAgentWithStateReport results in an error:
"AttributeError: No such RPC function 'report_state'".

This patch changes l3_agent_manager to be L3NATAgent instead of
L3NATAgentWithStateReport since all plugins do not support
L3NATAgentWithStateReport and having this as the default breaks
all current deployments that upgrade source without changing
their config files.

Fixes bug 1139726

Change-Id: Ibb5c04c89bfad741ec43a372cbf97445f7b3d76c

'}]
commit_message:
Set l3_agent_manager for ovs/linuxbridge plugin

related to quantum bug 1139726, L3NATAgentWithStateReport makes
no longer the default, as doing so broke DHCP for other plugins.

Quantum linuxbridge has the agent extension support. This commit also
set dhcp/l3_agent_manager to *AgentWithStateReport in linuxbridge plugin.

Change-Id: I4095f4276499468d02265169cc26bbd8489679bc

commit_message:
Add some useful log to filter scheduler.

When the filter scheduler is unable to find a suitable host to
deploy a volume on it simply logged a warning "not hosts found".
This isn't very helpful, so this patch adds some logging info as
far as why no valid host was available.  This just focuses on the
capacity filtering as that's where I've commonly seen this issue
particularly in tempest runs.

Also noticed that the get status was checking for "if Not capacity",
but this is wrong because free capacity==0 would be interpretted as
failing to get capacity.  Change this to "if is None".

Fixes bug: 1136147

Change-Id: Ia1ce508826ee69ae68a250ea68616909c59974e5

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-03-02 18:52:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

dims: max_depth was initially hard coded at 3... and was meant primarily as a means of avoiding cyclical data structures (the function uses recursion). We actually hit that max_depth in several cases in Nova... and we have for a long time.

When a94b9b4 went in (a month ago) it made an assumption that hitting max_depth was something to be Logged as an error. That doesn't appear to me to jive with the initial intent of this function.

If we want to add log an error or raise when max_depth is hit I think the thing to do would be to add an extra option for that explicitly and not change the historical default of this function. So perhaps the thing to do is revert this now... and follow it up with another commit to add the new feature for logging/raising when max_depth is hit."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-03-02 23:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Don't LOG.error on max_depth (by default).

Reverts part of a94b9b4 which added an extra LOG.error
statement when max_depth is hit.

This is causing spurious errors to get logged in some of our
projects which have adopted this changed.

Related to: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1140133

Change-Id: Ie7939e41797da000dd8b269f905f351df0b7116d

[{'created': '2013-02-28 14:04:59.000000000', 'message': "Modify drivers to return a list of protocols.

Drivers currently report 'storage_protocol', which is currently a
string value. This inhibits a driver from supporting more than one
protocol. Change value to a list of strings.

Fixes bug: 1135758

Change-Id: I7f12c7b3e00dc49047b18f56095812f430a9d7d1
"}]
commit_message:
Modify drivers to return a list of protocols.

Drivers currently report 'storage_protocol', which is currently a
string value. This inhibits a driver from supporting more than one
protocol. Change value to a list of strings.

Fixes bug: 1135758

Change-Id: I7f12c7b3e00dc49047b18f56095812f430a9d7d1

Bug #1135793

In addition, we refactor agent scheduler so that we will make
it easier to enable plugin to support agent scheduler.

A small change for dhcp agent schedule: we remove scheduling network
to dhcp agent when creating network so that we can give admin
the chance to allocate the given network to a given dhcp agent after
network creation.

commit_message:
enable linuxbridge for agent scheduler

Bug #1135793
blueprint quantum-scheduler

In addition, we refactor agent scheduler so that we will make
it easier to enable plugin to support agent scheduler.

Change-Id: I0d5cc8bcea644720a3c5cbe92486ce8d8ecd248c

How to run svc agent:
1. Enable LBaaS extension, scheduler and dummy loadbalancer driver - in quantum.conf:
# Quantum plugin provider module
core_plugin = quantum.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_quantum_plugin.OVSQuantumPluginV2

# Advanced service modules
service_plugins = quantum.plugins.services.loadbalancer.loadbalancerPlugin.LoadBalancerPlugin

# Service schedulers
service_schedulers = LOADBALANCER:quantum.plugins.services.loadbalancer.scheduler.schedulers.DevicePoolScheduler
balancer_devices_definitions = devices.json

# Loadbalancer drivers
service_drivers = quantum.tests.unit.drivers.dummy.dummy_driver.DummyDriver

2. Create devices.json, that file is needed for scheduler and contains list of LB devices:
{ "devices":[
    {
        "name":"device1",
        "type":"dummy",
        "version":"1.0",
        "management":{
            "ip":"172.18.76.107",
            "port":"22",
            "login":"developer",
            "password":"swordfish"
        }
    }
]
}

3. Run quantum-svc-agent --config-file=etc/quantum.conf.local --debug

LBaaS may be accessed via REST API (http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum/LBaaS/API_1.0) or via CLI (merged today)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-03 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
The change implements advanced services agent

Implements: blueprint lbaas-agent-and-rpc

In details:
* New agent for handling advanced services RPC commands
* Load balancer driver API
* Update of loadbalancer plugin to use RPC
* Dummy driver for testing purposes

Change-Id: I78f0b2e052616ee9e1851183353136d7be527133

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-02 19:29:51.000000000', 'message': "v1 api image-list does not return shared images

The addition of the status column on image_members for the v2 api broke
backwards compatibility with the v1 api image members feature. This fix
updates the migration that added the status column to default to 'accepted'
instead of 'pending' for existing shared images. It also forces that
member_status='all' is passed to all v1 api calls to ensure the v1 image
members feature still works.

Change-Id: I0ab9397e3663c6e2af8a18838f56803e64d84595
Fixes: bug #1132294
"}, {'created': '2013-03-02 23:47:56.000000000', 'message': "v1 api image-list does not return shared images

The addition of the status column on image_members for the v2 api broke
backwards compatibility with the v1 api image members feature. This fix
forces that member_status='all' is passed to all v1 api calls to ensure
the v1 image members feature still works.

Note: Any images shared prior to migration 016 will be marked as 'pending'
yet will still be accessible via the v1 api since v1 has no notion of
image 'member_status'. Additionally, any new images shared via the v1 api
will follow the same behavior, being marked as 'pending'. In order for
shared images to be used with v2 they will need to have a 'member_status'
of 'accepted'.

Change-Id: I0ab9397e3663c6e2af8a18838f56803e64d84595
Fixes: bug #1132294
DocImpact
"}]
commit_message:
v1 api image-list does not return shared images

The addition of the status column on image_members for the v2 api broke
backwards compatibility with the v1 api image members feature. This fix
forces that member_status='all' is passed to all v1 api calls to ensure
the v1 image members feature still works.

Note: Any images shared prior to migration 016 will be marked as 'pending'
yet will still be accessible via the v1 api since v1 has no notion of
image 'member_status'. Additionally, any new images shared via the v1 api
will follow the same behavior, being marked as 'pending'. In order for
shared images to be used with v2 they will need to have a 'member_status'
of 'accepted'.

Change-Id: I0ab9397e3663c6e2af8a18838f56803e64d84595
Fixes: bug #1132294
DocImpact

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-01 23:23:58.000000000', 'message': 'Set vm_state to ERROR on net deallocate failure.

If deallocate_network_for_instance from network.api fails while trying
to terminate an instance, set the vm_state to ERROR.  Previously it
still completely failed at this point, but the instance vm_state was
still ACTIVE but the task_state was stuck in deleting.  Now it will be
ERROR/deleting.

Fix bug 1110221.

Change-Id: I181a11c8de667fa462e1a2cb75b2c8ae41410273
'}]
commit_message:
Set vm_state to ERROR on net deallocate failure.

If deallocate_network_for_instance from network.api fails while trying
to terminate an instance, set the vm_state to ERROR.  Previously it
still completely failed at this point, but the instance vm_state was
still ACTIVE but the task_state was stuck in deleting.  Now it will be
ERROR/deleting.

Fix bug 1110221.

Change-Id: I181a11c8de667fa462e1a2cb75b2c8ae41410273

commit_message:
Test date with UTC instead of local timezone.

iso_format test uses local timezone so it can fail at certain times
of the day depending on which timezone the tests are run in.

Fixes bug 1139131

Change-Id: I8fe423d96c438b46a9307fe1ecf648707183ff1c

commit_message:
Update db layer to expose multiple image locations

* The DB API now exposes a 'locations' image attribute rather than
  'location'. The new field is guaranteed to be a list of zero of
  more items
* The v1 and v2 APIs only look for the first item in the list of
  locations.
* Related to bp multiple-image-locations

Change-Id: I830b383d8a8e50a01e461658fb9abe384de1a353

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-28 23:02:45.000000000', 'message': 'Implement rules_exist method for quantum security group driver

Originally I thought the quantum security group driver should
not enforce rules exist on the nova-api side and instead it should
just forward the request to quantum which would return the error.
That said there is no extra cost to doing this on the nova-api side
as nova-api already queries for the group before adding the rule.

In addition, rules_exists() is used in revoke_security_group_ingress()
for the ec2 compat APIs so this needs to be implemented.

This patch moves create_security_group_rule() and rule_exists() from
nova/compute/api.py to nova/network/security_group/security_group_base.py
as the same code can be leveraged in both places.

Fixes bug 1136345

Change-Id: I444ffc2b53b30ed496b6e3250433d14f316e594d
'}, {'created': '2013-03-01 18:43:51.000000000', 'message': 'Implement rules_exist method for quantum security group driver

Originally I thought the quantum security group driver should
not enforce rules exist on the nova-api side and instead it should
just forward the request to quantum which would return the error.
That said there is no extra cost to doing this on the nova-api side
as nova-api already queries for the group before adding the rule.

In addition, rules_exists() is used in revoke_security_group_ingress()
for the ec2 compat APIs so this needs to be implemented.

This patch moves create_security_group_rule() and rule_exists() from
nova/compute/api.py to nova/network/security_group/security_group_base.py
as the same code can be leveraged in both places.

Fixes bug 1136345

Change-Id: I444ffc2b53b30ed496b6e3250433d14f316e594d
'}]
commit_message:
Implement rules_exist method for quantum security group driver

Originally I thought the quantum security group driver should
not enforce rules exist on the nova-api side and instead it should
just forward the request to quantum which would return the error.
That said there is no extra cost to doing this on the nova-api side
as nova-api already queries for the group before adding the rule.

In addition, rules_exists() is used in revoke_security_group_ingress()
for the ec2 compat APIs so this needs to be implemented.

This patch moves create_security_group_rule() and rule_exists() from
nova/compute/api.py to nova/network/security_group/security_group_base.py
as the same code can be leveraged in both places.

Fixes bug 1136345

Change-Id: I444ffc2b53b30ed496b6e3250433d14f316e594d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-01 12:44:41.000000000', 'message': 'Allow qpid to be selected as AMQP provider on precise

Fixes bug 1137667

Previously the auth/sasl config for qpidd was broken, and the
openstack services using RPC were not properly configured.

Now we ensure that:

- the admin qpid_username/password are configured for all services
  (as the qpidd ACL config denies all access to non-admin users)

- the PLAIN sasl mechanism is configured for qpidd (otherwise the
  qpid_password is not propogated)

- the qpidd process has read permission on the sasl DB (otherwise
  thw admin user/apss cannot be verified even if set)

Change-Id: Id6bd675841884451b78f257afe786f494a03c0f7
'}]
commit_message:
Allow qpid to be selected as AMQP provider on precise

Fixes bug 1137667

Previously the auth/sasl config for qpidd was broken, and the
openstack services using RPC were not properly configured.

Now we ensure that:

- the admin qpid_username/password are configured for all services
  (as the qpidd ACL config denies all access to non-admin users)

- the PLAIN sasl mechanism is configured for qpidd (otherwise the
  qpid_password is not propogated)

- the qpidd process has read permission on the sasl DB (otherwise
  thw admin user/apss cannot be verified even if set)

Change-Id: Id6bd675841884451b78f257afe786f494a03c0f7

OK i have changed this to have all sw-* account enabled when specifying the 'swift' keyword.

This change from all other services because swift is not enabled by default and having to manually specify :

"sw-account sw-container sw-proxy sw-object"

in ENABLED_SERVICES to enable swift is awkward and not backward compatible.

If we had swift enabled by default, which should run 'swiftly' (sorry) with only one replica then it would definitively be easy to match the others but still not backward compatible.

WDYT?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-13 11:49:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Enable swift by default.

- Set by default SWIFT_REPLICAS to 1 since this is the most common use
  case when using it in devstack.
- If we have swift_replicas to 1 launch the object container account and
  proxy servers in foreground in screen.
- Allow any s- services if we have just 'swift' in service enabled
  instead of having to specify all s- services to enable swift. This will be
  removed in the future.

Change-Id: I496f79e14f99bd7e9f2c7deee12a4b6e935c3a5b

commit_message:
Host route to metadata server with Bigswitch/Floodlight Plugin

Host route to metadata server was not getting propagated
to VM when using the Big Switch/Floodlight plugin. The
reason being the update to the subnet (with the host
route information) was not being picked up by the dhcp
agent. This is being fixed here by sending a notification
to the dhcp agent when the host route is added to the subnet.

Fixes: Bug #1134043

Change-Id: If040f51946bcb734da319249df17d03e68aa5588

commit_message:
Move network schedule to first port creation.

blueprint quantum-scheduler

we remove scheduling network
to dhcp agent when creating network so that we can give admin
the chance to allocate the given network to a given dhcp agent after
network creation.

Change-Id: I228870669825405277de0505a3f2ece074918524

Relax version constraint on requests.

Ceilometer has no version-specific requests code and other componensts
allow requests>=1.0 already.

'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-11 18:38:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

This a good cleanup, but I don't think you should change the names of the classes. just having a class name of XML or JSON isn't 100% clear at first glance. (It could be a XML util class for example)

I get that will be in the rest_client import, but I preferred it the other way. If there is a consensus the other against my opinion I'll change this to a +1."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-02-11 18:47:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Don't you remove T302 enforcement in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21079/?"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-11 18:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-02-11 19:32:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I mostly agree with Matt. Class names should not be so generic unless they really  represent something that generic. But as a larger issue, names for things in code are always a source of disagreement among developers based on taste, and people learn code with the names that are there. It is hard enough to keep on top of a growing and changing code base.  I think we should resist this kind of name change unless it can be clearly stated why the existing name is bad. It is also better to have that discussion before code is submitted, either through a bug ticket or chat or ML, etc.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-11 20:21:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"- Do not import objects, only modules (*)"

It is in the HACKING.rst.

We can just import the rest_client, since it is a modul.
We can just use it as rest_client.RestClient.

So it cannot collide with any other XML or JSON usage.

@jogo:
I wanted to remove it just temporary, because of the inspection. 
(The beginning of the story is here:https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20687/ )


The clean module import rule actually not just style rule..'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-02-14 15:55:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Matt and David about the name change to just Base.

Other than that, I support the patch."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-14 16:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I will rename the file to rest.py and add back the "Client" word to classes name.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-17 09:47:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-17 10:53:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/2/check/gate-tempest-pep8/2175 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/3416 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/3139 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/7771 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/427 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2013-02-18 02:33:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't understand this change. The rest client is a base connector class, but I don't feel good about changing it's name to base_client. If we start adding other base clients (such as a command line client), things would get far too confusing."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-18 07:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The HTTP rest operations should go the rest.py, the ssh related things should go to the ssh.py.

The only common in these things they are using network socket.

It wont be confusing, since bacause of the module import rule, they always will be prefixed with the module name. So the sort module names are preferred.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:57:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm fine with the fix to switch over all the imports to import a module and not the class, that's a good cleanup. But, the rest of the change when you're moving the file and renaming the classes is not needed and in my opinion shouldn't be done. (Although maybe making separate RestClientJSON class to match RestClientXML would probably be fine) I get what you're saying that we'll have to make the calls with the module name in it after the change, but I don't think that warrants moving the file and renaming things.

Just leave rest_client.py in tempest/common and keep the classes named the same. All you should need to do is update the imports to import the rest_client module. There is nothing wrong with:

from tempest.common import rest_client

rest_client.RestClientJSON()"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-18 17:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Why would you repeat 2 words in the same expression ?'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-19 09:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 11:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/3/check/gate-tempest-pep8/2202 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/3909 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/3631 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/8348 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21643/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/450 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-02-21 16:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Look, we have to accept that different people have different opinions about this sort of thing. My opinion is that importing modules is not better than importing classes (who says it is and why, other than some highly-opinionated hacking guide we imported?), though it might make sense in some cases. But I can live with that. I have a stronger opinion that a class name should stand for what it is, within reasonable limits, and that having public classes with the same name in different modules causes incredible pain for new people trying to absorb code, particularly those who are using real IDEs.

I hope we don't start having language style wars. I don't see how this change makes the code easier to understand which is the most important thing when justifying the cost of a large renaming."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-22 12:04:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

No comment on the review, but we're trying to normalize style across projects. That hacking guide comes from nova, and I think it's good if as much as possible all OpenStack projects follow similar styles. It helps make it easy for developers to hop around between projects."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-22 12:16:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Matt.

Let's just make the T302 change, but don't move rest_client.py. It's an unrelated change, and I don't see what we get out of it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Using RestClient according to T302 rule

* The tempest/ is enough common location itself
* since we had to use the module name in imports we do not need to embed
  the RestClient name too

Change-Id: I0e3b0fc48c48766691794d1e77e5daa5726197a6

[{'created': '2013-02-22 04:47:37.000000000', 'message': "Limit the size of HTTP requests.

Adds a new RequestBodySizeLimiter middleware to guard against
really large HTTP requests. The default max request size is 112k
although this limit is configurable via the 'max_request_body_size'
config parameter.

Fixes LP Bug #1099025.

Change-Id: Id51be3d9a0d829d63d55a92dca61a39a17629785
"}]
commit_message:
Limit the size of HTTP requests.

Adds a new RequestBodySizeLimiter middleware to guard against
really large HTTP requests. The default max request size is 112k
although this limit is configurable via the 'max_request_body_size'
config parameter.

Fixes LP Bug #1099025.

Change-Id: Id51be3d9a0d829d63d55a92dca61a39a17629785

commit_message:
Fixes traceback issue with image data upload

1. Fixed exception raised in sending notification for v2 API
(due to image meta serialization issue).
2. Updated corresponding unit tests for notification checks.

Fixes LP: #1084001

Change-Id: I0d0d492589e0ca49316e52dc07ca9b45c44fd1a5

commit_message:
Libvirt driver to use current nova.network.model

Fixes: bug 1112646

* Updated tests to use VIF class instead of legacy "network,mapping" tuple.
* Modified libvirt/{driver,firewall,vif}.py to use VIF class instead of legacy
  "network,mapping" tuple.

Change-Id: Ic67291f3bfa7624af38061fa61a88ff16aa5acda

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:19:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The SmokeStack XenServer tests do an actual resize on a server which seems to go into an ERROR state with this branch.

I'll have to have a closer look to see what is going on here."}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:27:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I have tracked down the error - the override in api.py is not visible to manager.py.  The code needs to be refactored to do the override logic in both places.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-05 20:47:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

First, there is not implementation of this for the virt drivers, so setting these flags doesn't do anything. Adding config variables that don't have implementations in tree isn't really viable.

Second, I have a conceptual issue with this approach. resize is a user initiated API operation that is expected to succeed, or fail because resources were not available. If someone sets resize_to_same_host as require, and I try to convert from M to L guest on a full host, this is going to fail. The retry path for resize, if it's not a quota issue is to try again. Which will also fail. And now there is a UX loop where the user is trapped, and they have no idea why.

If "require" was changed to "preferred", the conceptual issue would go away, because then we would expect the user wouldn't get trapped. We still need an actual implementation across the drivers in tree though if we are going to take this, and with g-3 only days away, that needs to be available in a patch series right away.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-05 21:53:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

ok, ignore my virt drivers comment, as I missed a beat there. I still have an issue with the UX of this where resize_to_same_host="require" as it creates an edge condition where the user is stuck, and can't resolve their problem without admin intervention.'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-06 02:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-06 02:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

From a UX perspective, Sean Dague is right - in most setups, "require" is not the setting you want.  However, it is desirable in some environments to only have migrations be invoked explicitly (e.g. most PowerVM environments).  This should be captured as part of the documentation.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-06 03:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-08 17:51:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I still think this is a bad idea. The only reason the flag was there in the first place was so we could run tempest on devstack in the gate and test resize. Semantically this changes the meaning of resize in a way that I don't think should be done."}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-08 21:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Sean - reading the external API (http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2/content/Resize_Server-d1e3707.html) - not sure which semantic this breaks.  All this patch does is allow you to force the resize to occur on the same server.  It does not change the API or behavior; REVERT and CONFIRM work unchanged.  In some environments a live migration is undesirable and creating a "clone" within the same physical machine is preferred vs the network traffic (i.e. extremely large VMs or one with slower networks).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-14 22:41:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I understand what the patch does, and I even think it appears to be functionally correct based on what the intention appears to be.  However, I'm not convinced that the option is a useful addition.

First, it really just doesn't seem in the spirit of OpenStack or "cloud" to care this much about where the instance goes like this.  The existing option was only a hack for testing, not something expected for admins to care about.

If this really *is* something admins need to care about, I'd like to better understand why.   Further, if that's the case, I'm not sure a global config option is the right way to go about it.  I think it may make more sense to have this be API driven.  I'd like to see some thoughts from others on this point.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-14 23:00:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I completely agree with the "spirit of cloud" argument. I further think that exposing anything via the API that would support this (i.e. giving the users control or even indication of where their instance lands) is a dangerous precedent to set.

I tend to think that this use case is so small and specialized, that it belongs in some other sort of policy implementation, and definitely not as yet-another-config-option to be exposed to the admins. That, or in some other project entirely :)'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-15 12:37:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-15 12:42:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Addressed the case where the migrate API in admin_actions calls resize and this patch would have disallowed the explicit admin-initiated action.  Migrate is distinguished from Resize by flavor_id being None.'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-15 13:42:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Russell / Dan - I agree this is not an 80% use case, or probably even that popular in the other 20%, but resize today is the only user facing API that can trigger the migration of a VM to a new machine.  In some environments, this network traffic is undesirable - especially 1GBe - and may want to be explicitly controlled by an Administrator. In this implementation, an Admin can still invoke a migration manually to allow the resize to succeed.  I would point to the Island work by Sina as an example, they wrote an entire Cinder driver designed to minimize network traffic.

I agree with the point above that exposing this on an end-user API is not correct, users should not know or care where this goes.  However, as the cloud operator, I should be able to have that level of control and this puts it in their hands.

Obviously this option would need documented to allow administrators to decide if they need to change it, but it certainly wouldn't be default.  Expectation is that it would of use in smaller installations or enterprise uses cases more often than service providers.  

Additionally, it continues to honor the existing resize API contract."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-15 13:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Build succeeded.

Once a review turns into a discussion about whether it is fundamentally acceptable, it should move to the openstack-dev list.  I would recommend raising a discussion there to see if you can gain some support for the patch.

However, given that feature freeze is less than a week away, it is extremely unlikely that this can make grizzly.'}, {'account_id': 1803, 'date': '2013-02-15 14:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Russell - will take to the ML.  Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-02 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-02 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2013-02-04 19:21:42.000000000', 'message': 'Optionally force instances to "stay put" on resize

Previously there was a boolean "allow_resize_to_same_host" config option
that would POTENTIALLY prevent an instance from moving on resize. While
this suffices for certain cases, it doesn't quite provide the
flexibility needed for some users. That is, an administrator may NEVER
want to allow a migration to occur as a side effect of a resize
operation.

As such, a new config option, "resize_to_same_host", was introduced and
can be any one of the following values: allow, require or forbid
(default, consistent with the old option). When its value is set to
"require", the "force_hosts" directive is passed along to the scheduler
so that it can make the appropriate decision.

Its predecessor, "allow_resize_to_same_host", has been deprecated; note
that backwards compatibility will be preserved. Test cases also added.

Change-Id: I09f50e3e5debe7c50d67e0f251323353625c83ec

commit_message:
Optionally force instances to "stay put" on resize

Previously there was a boolean "allow_resize_to_same_host" config option
that would POTENTIALLY prevent an instance from moving on resize. While
this suffices for certain cases, it doesn't quite provide the
flexibility needed for some users. That is, an administrator may NEVER
want to allow a migration to occur as a side effect of a resize
operation.

As such, a new config option, "resize_to_same_host", was introduced and
can be any one of the following values: allow, require or forbid
(default, consistent with the old option). When its value is set to
"require", the "force_hosts" directive is passed along to the scheduler
so that it can make the appropriate decision.

Its predecessor, "allow_resize_to_same_host", has been deprecated; note
that backwards compatibility will be preserved. Test cases also added.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint configurable-resize-placement
Change-Id: I09f50e3e5debe7c50d67e0f251323353625c83ec

commit_message:
Don't use instance['instance_type'] for scheduler filters in migration

Instead, pull a fresh copy from the database, which has the proper
extra_specs cleanup which everyone downstream of us expects.

Fixes bug 1136430

Change-Id: Ifcb9feff8291096eed7c198b8e7a35c3c38ca93e

[{'created': '2013-02-25 02:36:45.000000000', 'message': 'TempURL filename options; bug fixes

- Prior to this commit, a Content-Disposition header was always set
  on responses to GET requests, with the filename based on the object
  name. Now, the header will only be set for 2xx responses and the
  filename can be overridden with a filename query parameter on the
  request.

- Fixed a bug where all query parameters on the request were being
  passed down the WSGI pipeline. Now, just the query parameters
  useful in log-based debugging are included. This becomes important
  with things like the Bulk middleware that act upon query
  parameters.

Change-Id: I66ad809321dcdd03444324973c8b76869e3b0c8e

commit_message:
TempURL filename options; bug fixes

- Prior to this commit, a Content-Disposition header was always set
  on responses to GET requests, with the filename based on the object
  name. Now, the header will only be set for 2xx responses and the
  filename can be overridden with a filename query parameter on the
  request.

- Fixed a bug where all query parameters on the request were being
  passed down the WSGI pipeline. Now, just the query parameters
  useful in log-based debugging are included. This becomes important
  with things like the Bulk middleware that act upon query
  parameters.

- Fixed bug where the Content-Disposition header wasn't following RFC
  spec.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I66ad809321dcdd03444324973c8b76869e3b0c8e

commit_message:
Unpin PasteDeploy dependency version

Fixes bug #1133262

There are no newer releases of PasteDeploy than 1.5.0 and we have no
reason to believe newer versions will break us. Indeed, if an
incompatible version is released, we will want to know about it quickly.

Change-Id: I331b33b16ea50202886b19bf5c4060d9fa46d5ec

commit_message:
Replace direct tempfile usage with a fixture.

tempfiles should always be created in fixtures to ensure that they actually
get cleaned up when we're done.

Change-Id: If4eee03b2e9ec6bd5333b8d5022ec9809343584e

commit_message:
fix update_port to get tenant_id from db rather than request

This patch changes the behavor of nvp's update_port() to how it previously
worked by retrieving the value from the db and not the request.

Fixes bug 1138330

Change-Id: I49682db392954b3cfaeb4ad4b8acf95113dcae7e

commit_message:
Sync latest setup.py from oslo.

This commit syncs the lastest version of setup.py from oslo,
which includes:

8842a00 openstack.common.setup: fails to get version from git
8ce5947 Change the check for the existence of .git directory.
7417a60 returncode for Popen is valid only after communicate call

Change-Id: I491381b2f9cb178bb1d9aa9e790cc7fd11a67d2f

commit_message:
Sync latest install_venv_common.py

Syncs:

c78b2ab Avoid using cfg in install_venv_common

So that people don't need oslo-config installed to run install_venv

Change-Id: Ie9b703255e8fdd1faa32b4e995efd858b3801801

commit_message:
validate security_groups on server create

security_groups were getting passed all the way into the database
without ever checking for their existance. This allowed for crudding
up the db with bad data, as well as succeeding when an admin typoed
a security group, and getting no active security group.

Also, security_group is actually an array, which is not implied by
it being a singular variable. Make it a plural variable to cause
less confusion in the future.

And given that we multiply change security_groups from None =>
['default'], get rid of a utility function that serves no purpose
to handle the None or string cases.

To test this correctly, stub out the db call, so we manage to get
all the way down to the bottom of the stack sanely. Also ensure that
the negative case gets us the expected HTTPBadRequest.

Partial fix for nova bugs needed to reenable test_servers_negative
in Tempest. Fixes bug #1046870

Change-Id: I5b477f7bc1992abb47e014f137b8010cc76b2113

[{'created': '2013-02-25 15:42:20.000000000', 'message': "instance_info_cache_update creates wrongly

If instance_info_cache_update() finds that the entry doesn't exist, it
attempts to create an entry, but it doesn't use all of the data.

Fixes bug 1131594

Change-Id: Id008faf5c4a48ab6a04e75796b7e61dea102acc9
"}, {'created': '2013-03-01 17:03:34.000000000', 'message': "instance_info_cache_update creates wrongly

If instance_info_cache_update() finds that the entry doesn't exist, it
attempts to create an entry, but it didn't use all of the data. This
patch fixes that.

Also if the info_cache entry was found to be deleted, the old code would
attempt to create a new entry.  This would have failed with
DBDuplicateEntry..  Instead, raise InstanceInfoCacheNotFound, which is
more appropriate. (It doesn't seem we actually ever hit this case.)

Fixes bug 1131594

Change-Id: Id008faf5c4a48ab6a04e75796b7e61dea102acc9
"}]
commit_message:
instance_info_cache_update creates wrongly

If instance_info_cache_update() finds that the entry doesn't exist, it
attempts to create an entry, but it didn't use all of the data. This
patch fixes that.

Also if the info_cache entry was found to be deleted, the old code would
attempt to create a new entry.  This would have failed with
DBDuplicateEntry..  Instead, raise InstanceInfoCacheNotFound, which is
more appropriate. (It doesn't seem we actually ever hit this case.)

Fixes bug 1131594

Change-Id: Id008faf5c4a48ab6a04e75796b7e61dea102acc9

commit_message:
Improve output msgs for _compare_result

In case of errors, the messages are now more detailed.
Fixes bug 1133621

Change-Id: I7747d7c4dcaf2199dc55139ee0235f6adca1ad36

port id that the user requested. However, if they do not pass one (which
is valid) then we can not do the filter and we fail. This makes the
allocation function do the filtering, which should not affect the normal

commit_message:
Make allocate_for_instance() return only info about ports allocated

Previously, the compute manager was filtering the results based on the
port id that the user requested. However, if they do not pass one (which
is valid) then we can not do the filter and we fail. This makes the
allocation function do the filtering, which should not affect the normal
use case where it is only called once, since all the ports returned were
allocated at that time.

The manager filter behavior is thus removed and a test is added to
verify that the allocate method does the right thing the second time
around.

This fixes the fallout found after fixing the actual cause of bug 1131264

Change-Id: I8f3af96051268503596007491af365e8ce28f5b3

Good point, I'll have to do some thinking on that. I *think* we're okay since, as you say, the database thinks the instance belongs here, but I'll have to check and see if there are reasonable windows where that might be incorrect.

That aside, can you comment on the required powervm change(s) required if we go forward with this? :)"}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-02-25 22:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The powervm driver should be OK, as long as we can know the "new" instance is cleaned up and all the resources it might have allocated get released (block devices, vifs, etc.) After that a revert should run fine.

The only other thought on it I would have would be rolling back a resize. Do we know the instance flavor would get properly reset to the previous one?
There is a lot of DB housekeeping involved here...'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-25 23:04:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My concern in the powervm case is indeed making sure there isn't a guest left on the destination, or on the local machine that will prevent the rename from happening again.

I don't think the flavor thing is a problem because I don't think it has been converted to the new one if we're still in this task_state, but I'll take a look."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-26 00:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-26 01:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

We should make sure that the '-orig' VM actually exists first before wiping what we'd rename it to...  (Now that I said this, I wonder if your patch ends up doing this.. )"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-28 17:03:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Make compute manager revert crashed migrations on init_host()

This should provide a path to cleanup partial migrations by reverting
them back to the original state instead of leaving them in limbo. Note
that libvirt needs a change to make this work, in the case where the
unconfirmed instance's directory is still present and needs to be
removed before the rollback.

The libvirt, xenapi and powervm drivers are modified here, and tests
are added to confirm their compliance with the proper behavior.

Addresses bug 1131588

Change-Id: I85bc0f6e9cda10aa85328199d107a3ff6e240b96

commit_message:
Improve hackings docstring detection

Previously: def foo():\n    a = '''This is not a docstring'''
would be counted as a docstring even though it isn't.

Fix this and add docstring tests.

Fix bug 1100912

Change-Id: Id4d4aa382713eea340720e166e418262ba68eaaf
